Entry.1:
August. 28/ 1916

Dull and cloudy all day. No rain. Shoeing mules in the morning and horses in the evening. at the school of Farriery South Camp. Romsey. 

After tea I saw a trashing machine trashing oats at a neighbouring farm. The trasher was driven by a traction engine & there were elevators to carry the straw to the top of the stack.
Entry.2:
Dull & cloudy ,and showery at breakfast time which continued

all day. Our class put on pair of front shoes on a mule before breakfast and another before dinner. In the afternoon our class was removed to forge 28 under Sargeant Cobele for more advanced work. Heavy rain fell in the evening. The ground was covered with sheets of water. The rain continued during the night.
Entry.3: The rain cleared away after breakfast & it was fine but cloudy all day. We put on 18 shoes to day, and were not over worked.
Entry.4:
A cloudy day but fine. Shoeing horses all day. After tea I walked into Romsey, and had look at Mr. Holloways flour mill. Mr. Holloway showed me all over the mill. There are two mills both worked by water wheels, and they are both of the stove pattern. The first is driven by a wooden water wheel of 20 Horse Power and the water runs under the wheel. This is called the undershot style. The other wheel is much wider and larger in diameter. It is made of iron and 

and steel. The stream of water strikes the wheel nearly half way up and this style is known as the brest shot. This wheel developes 80 H. P. In both mills the wheat or other grain is ground by revolving stones. The grain entering through the centre of the top stone and as it revolves the grain is crushed and works to the outside. The bottom stone remains stationary all the time. These stones cost about £30 each, are about 4ft in diameter and 10 in thick. There are a number of other machines in the mill for sifting the flour.
Entry.5:
Showery this morning no shoeing before breakfast. We put on 10 shoes before dinner and also had a lecture by Sgt. Cobele on the anatomy and diseases of the horses foot. The following disease will be cured or greatly relived by using for seedy toe cameral, or white mercury powder cameral is a very heavy white powder made from mercury. 

Trush, carbolic acid, put on with a feather. 

Corns, bran poultice, after poulticing, shoe ,and

ease the pressure, and also keep clean. 

This morning there was an examination of those students who have been in the school some time. 

After dinner a medical inspection of the whole school, to see if all were in good health. Then an inspection of the tents. At 3. 30 pay for the English soldiers, and no work for all hands. We had the afternoon off. 

There is a mail for Australia on Sept. 7 via the Suez. Another on the same day via Vancouver and another on Sept 8. via San Francisco. Correspendence to be forwarded by these routes must be specially so addressed. Published in the "Times" of today. 

I was on Fire Piquett tonight , dressed and answered the roll at 6 p. m.
Entry.6:
A very showery morning, No work before breakfast. Went to bed after answering the roll. Our class put on 17 shoes before dinner. I fitted 8 shoes on a light hack & nailed on 4. 

After dinner I with Pope & J. W. Dalziel obtained a leave pass and caught the 2. 45 train to Southampton. 

On the way we passed through Nurseling, Redbridge, Millbrook. We stayed at 50 Portland Terrace Southampton, which is a small boarding house of 3 stories. At night we had a walk around the city and out on the pier and went to bed very late.
Entry.7:
Got up late this morning & had a walk round the city before breakfast. Then with A. Pope we went for a long walk past the gardens where there are some fine monuments. One recently erected commemorates the memory of the brave engineers who stood by their post when the S. S. Titanic struck an iceberg in the Atlantic Ocean on her maiden voyage to America. 

We then went down the for above 2 miles. There is a forest of oak trees on both sides and an electric tramline down the centre of the road. Then we came back & sat in the park until dinner time. There are many beautiful churches near the park. Southampton is a very old town, In high st. there is a stone bridge

across the street called Bar gate, which marked the Northern boundary in olden times. The central arch is for vehicle traffic. The electric tram line also runs through it. The smaller arches on each side is for pedestrians. The rooms above the bridge are now used for police courts. . There is a long high wall on the sea shore which was built in the 14th century and used as a defence for the town against attack from the sea. In the evening I had a walk around another quarter of the city & saw a very big church with a spire. The church was surrounded by a high wall, out on the gate posts there were carved head in stone. The church yard was filled with graves over which there were many ancient tombstones. 

At 8 oclock we caught the train for home, As there was no train direct to Romsey we took a train to Eastleigh or Bishopstoke. There we changed for Romsey which we reached at 9 p. m. passing a little station on

the way. This was a roundabout route, but the fare was the same viz. 8d.
Entry.8:
A fine day but cloudy. After breakfast we were (Australians) marched to the Veternary Hospital, and after considerable delay marched back again to our own camp. The arrangements to go to the Hospital being cancelled. We had to draw blankets ,boards & matresses, again for we handed them in to the store before we left. There was steady rain this evening, & there is every appearance of a wet night. 

This evening a lot more Australians came into the school from other units. There were also a lot of English Tommies.
Entry.9: A quiet day and not much work to do . After tea I walked into Romsey & posted Lizzie 3 dozen post card views of places I have seen in England and S. . Africa. I also wrote to Willie
Entry.10:
Shoeing all day. 

We shod 4 draught horses. l I was on guard tonight for the first time. My watch was from 10 to 12 and from 4 to 6.
Entry.11: A warm beautiful day. Our class shod 1 horse this morning then we had a lecture by the Vet. Lieut. McNaut on the diseases of the horses foot. Seedy toe, , Sand Crack & corns also Laminitus or drop sole.
Entry.12: A nice day but cloudy. Shoeing draught horses this morning. A lecture by the Vet before dinner on diseases of the horse’s foot that can be remedied by shoeing & questions on the lecture we had yesterday. A draught horse stood on my foot this morning& I got it painted with iodine this evening. Revallie this morning was altered from 5. 30 a. m. to 5. 45 a. m.
Entry.13: A dull cloudy day but fine. On parade this morning new orders were read out. Revellie 6a. m. breakfast 7 a. m. Shoeing up to 11. 45 and a lecture by the Vet. on the horse’s foot, being mainly a repetition of previous lectures. In the evening went into Romsey for a walk.
Entry.14: At 10. 30 this morning we had a lecture by the Vet. on the structure of the horse’s foot and questions in previous lectures. I wrote to Gerard L. Henning Seymour, today. I also got two letters from Lizzie today dated June 7&21 & one from Willie. June 20.
Entry.15: A cloudy day, but fine. Shoeing all day, but not many hooves shod. I fitted and nailed on 4 shoes. There is a concert tonight in the Recreation tent, which I attended. The programme was a long one. Many of the items were very good.
Entry.16: A cool cloudy day. Shoeing all day. There was a lecture before dinner by the Farrier Major on the horse’s foot and questions on it. After tea, I walked to Totton by myself. It is 41/4 miles from the south camp. I got some postcard views of the place. It is a fairly large village, and has a sawmill and a brewery.
Entry.17: It was fairly warm this afternoon, and windy after tea. Shoeing all day except for ¾ of an hour before dinner when the Farrier Sgt Major gave a lecture on shoeing and the structure of the horse’s foot.
Entry.18: A fine day but cold at night. Shoeing horses in the morning&mules in the evening. The Vet. Mr McNaught gave a lecture this morning&asked a number of questions to prepare us for the examination which is ti take place tomorrow.
Entry.19:
There was an examination today by the board of Inspectors for the School of Farriers. I was one of those who passed. The examination consisted of fitting one front shoe cold and nailing it on. Also answering a number of questions relating to the structure of the foot, the functions of the various parts and questions on shoeing, and sheing for various defects. 

THE "Daily Mail" Picture post cards are now out. I got Series III No’s 17 to 24 at 6d.
Entry.20: A fine morning but cloudy & threatening rain. After breakfast we assembled at 8. 30 roll call, & railway passes for Amesbury. We then marched into Romsey giving cheers for the Sergeants as we went. We passed the Vet Mr. McNaught & gave him a cheer. At 2 to 11 am we boarded our train for Salisbury & arrived there about 12. We changed trains here & arrived in Amesbury about 2 o‘clock. I started to walk out to the camp but got a ride before I went very far. I reported at Head Quarters soon after I arrived.
Entry.21:
A cloudy day. A lot of aeroplanes were about last night & this morning. I was helping the Pioneers this morning & after dinner went for a walk passed the 39 Battalion where I saw J. W. Dalziel, to the GERMAN Prison. This prison was recently

constructed and is made out of barbed wire & posts. Inside are huts and cook houses. There are close on 200 prisoners inside. They are all young fellows, and have been only about a week here.
Entry.22:
A very wet morning. At 9 o‘clock I was sent up to the shoeing forge with one of the Transport men, Driver with 2 horses to be shod. & put a set of slippers on one & set of shoes on the other. Also a slipper on a horse fromBrigade Headquarters, I had them all finished before dinner. I had nothing to do this evening . I was with the Transports talking. I saw Lieut. Hunter who was formerly my sergeant in D. Company . He made arrangements for me to report to the Transport Sargeant every morning. and examine the horses, & note those that require shoeing or removing. I wrote to Lizzie last night

b
Entry.23:
Bitterly cold and 

cloudy with a strong wind. No rain, Finer in the evening. I removed and altered a pair of hind shoes on a light draught that was brushing very badly . C. 339 bay mare. I made a good job of it & was congratulated by the Transport Sargent.
Entry.24: A nice moring. No cold winds. I reported to the Transport Sargeant but there was nothing to do before breakfast. After breakfast I put on 2 sets of removes, and in the afternoon cleaned and sharpened my tools. There was a review march of the whole brigade this afternoon. I was out of it. My cousin Miss M. J. Gilmore was married today in Ireland.
Entry.25: A beautiful day . In the morning I was with the Transports measuring horses feet for shoes. In the afternoon I was with B. Company & some of the Transports on the Range Rifle Shooting.
Entry.26: A nice day but cloudy. All the Headquarters details went out to Beeches Farm to a Range there for rifle practice. We went past Figheldean, through Netheravon & thense on to the Range which is about 8 miles from Lark Hill Camp. Netheravon is a nice little village about the same size as Fighledean which is about a mile away. When we passed Netheravon we were quite close to the Flying School. We saw several aeroplanes loop the loop today. There is a fixed observation balloon floating every day now on the west side of Rollestone Camp. It is taken down every night.
Entry.27:
A fine day but cloudy. The Headquarters details with the exception of the Band went out to the Range this morning. We fired at 200 & 200 yards at disappearing targets. We had the gas masks on while shooting at these ranges. We also fired up 600 yards. We had dinner in the range & another dinner when came back. This is my

birthday today. I wonder where I will be this day next year. I hope it will be in Victoria and the war over, and all enjoying the peace & security of a successful & glorious victory.
Entry.28:
A cloudy day, but warm in the sunshine. I had to put on a shoe this morning, cold fitting. Last night a batch of German prisoners arrived by train to Amesbury. Most of them were wounded, and a great number were in stretchers. They were all recent captives and of all ages and looked very thin, They were taken to the camp in motor ambulances. Yesterday evening I wrote a descriptive article on Salisbury Plains which I will post home. At dinner time today a special edition of the "Weekly Despatch" announced that two Zeppelins were brought down in England – one official and one reported. It caused great joy and excitement in camp. The king is to visit Salisbury Plains on Tuesday to inspect the 10th Brigade

and a lot of preparations are to be made tomorrow
Entry.29: Cloudy but fine, bright sunshine in the middle of the day. I was with the Transports all day measuring horse feet for shoes. There are 12 hacks and 12 light draughts. Last night at 7 o‘clock one of the men in C. Company died from measles and pneumonia, His name was a few days ago another man in company died from the same causes. Measles and Pneumonia are very prevalent just now and there are also a lot of innflueniza colds about.
Entry.30:
Showery all morning. All the Headquarter Details with the exception of the transports fell in with the companies that they are attached to for sleeping & messing, in full marching order for a rehersal of the King‘s Review tomorrow. On the Battalion parade grounds , the companies were sized up and afterwards inspected by Brigader - General 

McNichol then marched to the Brigade parade grounds & fell in line with the other Battalions comprising the Brigade. Even the cheers led by the Brigadier were rehersed, then the whole Brigade marched to the Bulford parade grounds with other Brigades. There were estimated to be some 35000 troops on the grounds, and the review was a magnificent sight . There was a march past the saluting base, and cheers by all the troops, each Battalion in rotation. We brought our dinner with us & had a long spell in the afternoon. We arrived back in camp rather late.
Entry.31:
Cloudy & threatening rain. The 37 Battalion moved off to theBulfordparadegrounds, the other Battalions of the Brigade following, early in the morning. Arriving there we had a long wait there were already thousandsofsoldiers lined up, and for fully an

hour more continued to arrive. The King arrived after Eleven and with his staff and a number of officers rode down the long khaki line. A flag was hoisted when the King arrived and all stood at attention for a few minutes while the bands played a few bars of the National Hymn & I had a good view of the King as he rode past followed by the Royal Standard Bearer. When the inspection was over there was a march past the Saluting Base which took several hours. Here I had another view of the King. The march past was in column of line. Then we halted on the side of the road, cake was dinner. A light drizzling rain was falling most of the time. After a long wait in the rain the King and his staff rode down the road and each Battalion as the King rode past cheered his majesty the O. C. of each leading the cheers. Then we had a dreary walk home in the drizzling rain, arriving about 3. O‘clock. I had three good views of the King. He is looking much older than the photos show and his whiskers are tinged

with grey. He is only a little man, & in the evening appeared to be tired with the constant saluting. Just fancy saluting with the right hand every few minutes for at least a couple of hours on a stretch. The Australian troops assembled today day were the largest body of men I even saw assembled together. There were far more than yesterday. The total was something about and did not include all the Australians on Salisbury Plains. Major Storry announced that the right half Battalion ,A & B companies obtained 98 points in the march past.
Entry.32: On sick parade this morning got a bad cold & stiff leg.
Entry.33:
A miserable day. Paraded sick this morning, but the Doctor did not know what was wrong with me. Again paraded sick after dinner, when the temperature was 103 & the measles were showing on forehead & chest. Was sent into the tent hospital

where I am waiting to be taken to one of the Hospitals
Entry.34: In hospital after a long motor drive too sick to write much.
Entry.35: Still sick in bed on a milk diet only,feel very weak and tired.
Entry.36: Showery day. Still in bed on a milk & soda water diet. Temperature down to 100. 2 this evening. Still have great difficulty in writing. Had a look at paper another zeppelin brought down last night near London.
Entry.37: My temperature is still up to 100,& should be going down. The measle rash is still very prominent & all over my body. The Dr. examined me this morning.
Entry.38: much better today. Temperature again nominal 98
Entry.39:
Feel much better. Nominal temperature. Hope to be up tomorrow. The rash on my forehead

has disappeared. The name of the hospital is Brimstone Bottom and I am in ward 2. The address is Brimstone Bottom,Isolation Hospital ,Nr Ludgers Hall, Wilts. 

I wrote to C. Handock this evening.
Entry.40: Feel much better today. Still on a milk diet. Wrote to Miss Gilmore today
Entry.41: On the mend. Read a lot today in Munseys Magazine.
Entry.42:
Feel very much better today. Was up for breakfast. Had a glass after dinner , the first since I came into the Hospital. 

Got a letter this morning from Victoria from my wife & was very glad to hear from her.
Entry.43: A fine morning. Feel much better this morning. I was up early before breakfast. There are a number of patients going out of this ward this morning, convalescent.
Entry.44:
A dull cloudy day was up early, and helped to clean up & dust the ward. Feel pretty good today. I

finished reading a new book "The Secret Service Submarine" by Guy Thorne. 

It is an interesting story but lacking in technical knowledge & in all probability there is not a vestage of fact in the whole story. 

The chaplain from Peckam Downs again visited our ward to day and brought along some reading matter. I wrote a long account of the Kings review of Australian troops on the Bulford Parade Grounds on Sept 27. 1916. 34.
Entry.45:
It is much finer to day but still windy. 

I feel alright except for an occasional pain under the pinney. 

This afternoon there was a visit from the chief Medical officer who was on a tour of inspection. 

Later on the British Red Cross distributed tobacco and cigarettes. I got a packet of tobacco which was very welcome as I was out and had no money to buy any. We cannot draw pay while in hospital.
Entry.46: Cloudy weather. I was up early this morning. Had breakfast & helped to clean up the ward. I had a letter from V. Lightbody this morning. Just before dinner Captain (Chaplain) Davidson of the 37 Battalion paid us a visit & made kindly enquiries how we were getting on. He came from Lark Hill. I wrote to Lizzie today. 35.
Entry.47:
a dull morning. I got two letters from my wife this morning before breakfast. No. 8. & 10. I was delighted to get them. I am to be sent back to Lark Hill tomorrow

I had a visit from Victor Lightbody tonight. He was not allowed in so I went out to see him. It is over 5 years since I last saw him. He has not altered much.
Entry.48:
I was up early this morning, had a shave before breakfast and made preparations for leaving the Hospital this morning. At breakfast time I got a 

letter and bundle of newspapers from Miss Gilmore Ireland. 

I arrived by motor ambulance at Lark Hill safely after about a 10 mile drive reported to the office & to the doctor Drew my kit from the store and was put into hut 20 as 15 was isolated.
Entry.49:
A dull cloudy morning, but fine in the afternoon. Reported to the doctor for cough medicine. I was put on light duties yesterday by the doctor for 48 hours. . 

I saw Dave Mc. Kean this afternoon. He is now in the 37 Battalion B Company. Lewis machine gun section . I also saw Adden Pople of Meffigum & F. Spicer who used to work for Donald McLeod of Merrigum. I heard that Barney Cummins is in the 38 battalion and Newnham who used to be a Sargeant in the light horse at Seymour. He is now a private in the artillery. I had 3 doses of medicine today at the dispensary.
Entry.50:
Very frosty last night & cold. 

this morning. A dull cloudy day. I went to the dispensary and got 3 doses of cough medicine today. I have nothing to do only keep out of the road. This afternoon a polling booth was held in the reading room of our camp for the purpose of allowing soldiers to vote on the conscription of slackers in Australia. The Australian vote will be taken on the 28. The majority of the soldiers are in favour of conscription including myself. Tonight an address was given in the dining room by Colonel (Chaplain) Crookston who is chaplain General on the French front. The address was a very inspiring one & was greatly appreciated by the large audience. The address was based on a passage from St John " A sea of glass & fire". The chaplain General of the Australian forces Colonel (Dr) L. Rentoul, "Fighting lary as he is known in Australia presided. He was an excellent chairman and gave a splendid opening address, in which he touched on the need of unity, the high ideals we are fighting for, and the need of conscription to rope in the slackers. The

37 Band was in attendance and played several airs before the meeting started.
Entry.51: A dull cloudy showery day. The 37 Battalion went on a march this morning. The transports took blankets for them. They will not be back until Friday evening. I was left in camp to look after the hot water and keep an eye on the pioneers work to see that it is done right. I done some washing today.
Entry.52:
A dull cloudy day but scarcely any rain. Stoking the hot water boiler in the Bathroom. I done a lot more washing today. I wrote to Miss Gilmore last night telling her that I was to get my leave on Saturday and that it was my intention to go to Kesh Ireland. I also wrote to my wife letter 39. I got a letter tonight from my wife dated Sept 3 and numbered 14. Letters No. 10. 12. & 13 not yet to hand. 

No 13 came Oct 21.
Entry.53:
I was stoking the boiler today. I also cleaned out all the bath rooms before dinner, and wheeled

some coal over to the boiler room. & took away the ashes to the tip. I had a busy day of it. 

I heard today that Toney Abrahamson died of wounds on the 28th of July in France & that Gus White was killed in action on August 20. 1916 in France.
Entry.54:
A nice morning & bright sunshine, the weather has taken up a bit. I was stoking the boiler again today . I have been my own Boss this week. The Battalion came back this afternoon about 4 o‘clock. I got a wire this evening from Miss Kithy Gilmore I should have got it yesterday informing me that there was no train on Sunday any further than Coaves & advising me to go on Friday but that was impossible because I did not get the wire in time also because the Battalion was away on the stunt, & there was no one here to give me leave. I tried to get 2 days indulgence leave in addition to the 4 days

the doctor recommended it, but there was no one in camp – not even the colonel – who could grant it unless it was recommended by the chief medical officer of the Brigade.
Entry.55:
A nice day but cold & frosty. I wheeled two barrow loads of coal to the boiler & helped to take away some ashes. I could not go to Ireland this morning as the trains did not run all the way to Kesh on Sunday from Belfast . 

I was paid £2 – last night & by waiting to next week, probably Wednesday, I will get 10/- more – that will make £3-10-0 whith what I had previously. 

This afternoon I with C. Hardock & J. Mathews walked into Amesbury. I got a few post cards. We had tea there. I got a letter from my dear wife today No13 and dated Aug. 27. 1916. Enclosed were some violets.
Entry.56:
Dull, cold, cloudy weather. I was doing the usual pioneer work this morning. This afternoon

I am writing letters
Entry.57: Dull cloudy weather. I with Mathews was shoeing this morning . We shod No 24 all round with size 6 shoes. We were measuring horses feet and tightening shoes this afternoon.
Entry.58: Dull & cloudy weather but not so cold. Mathews & I shod the Brushing horse this morning and examined some mules in the afternoon. This was all the work we done today. We urgently need a forge of our own, as the other forge is too far away and we cannot always get it.
Entry.59:
Cloudy showery weather and plenty of mud about. We examined the transport horses this morning. 

I got my colours this morning. Most of the Battalion already has got them. They cost 2d per pair. The 27 battalion colours are Black and red in the shape of a football & sewn on the shoulder 1 in below the shoulder strap. 

I got my ticket or rather paid for it today to Belfast and a voucher to Kesh. I will get my pass in the 

morning. I posted a post card (Christmas Greetings) to my wife tonight and a letter No41.
Entry.60:
A nice clear frosty morning. I got my pass before breakfast and am procceding to London enroute for Fleetwood and Belfast. I arrived at Waterloo Station at 12. 7 the train being 8 minutes late. From there I took an electric tube train, changed and went down a lift and took a tube to Euston arriving there at 20 to 1. Had dinner & then had a look around the station. I forgot to say that it was 20 to 10 when we left Amesbury. I was invited by the guard to travel in his van and get a good view of the country. 

We passed through the following stations from Amesbury to London. Amesbury, Newton Tony, Grabeley, Andover Jn. Hurstborne, Whichurch, Overton, Oakly, Basingate, Hook Winchfield, Fleet, Farnbourgh, Brookwood, Woking. Byfleet, Weybridge, Walton, Esher, Surbiton, Malden, Raynes Pk, 

Wimbledon, Earlsfield, Clapham Jun, Vauxhall, Waterloo. 

Brookwood is noted because it has the only cemetery in England that contain two public houses. 

At 5. 20 I left Euston station for Fleetwood. The first stopping place was at Stafford which we reached at 8 o‘clock. There are large shell works here owned by a German firm Simens. It also has a large jail. The next place we stopped at was at Crewe which is the largest railway centre in England. We reached Preston at 10 p. m. where I had a cup of tea. Preston has the largest cotton mill in the world. We reached Fleetwood at 20 to 11. 

The train steamed right on to the pier along side the steamer –Duke of Connaugh. It was the boat train from Euston to Fleetwood that I was aboard. There was no changing & it ran at express speed, passing through all small stations.
Entry.61:
As soon as the baggage was all aboard the steamer moved off. The sea was calm & we had a good passage across the Irish Sea. No one was sick. I had no bed so lay down on the "tween

decks. I had several drinks of Rum I think the best I ever tasted. The steamer arrived at Belfast at 7 o‘clock passing Harland & Wolfes dock yards on the way. There was a new ship on the chocks in the course of construction. At the pier we were met by a red cross man and taken to the red cross free buffet for breakfast. After breakfast I was put on a tram to the Great Northern Railway Station passing a monument of the Prince Consort and the city Hall on the way. The train did not go out until 9. 30 for Kesh. The ticket was 7/10. While in Belfast I some formed an impression of the people of Ireland. I was not more than 10 minutes in conversation with the people until I knew their politics and religion At the barbers shop the barber like all others of his calling the world over was very talkative. He soon let me know that he was a strong nationalist & RC At the Red cross buffet the ladies were strongly imperialist. At the N. S. buffett the ladies their were imperialist. However they were all very kind despite their strong and outspoken 

opinions. An Irishman or Irishwoman is never divided or halted between two opinions. He or she is either on one side or the other, and apparently is ready to fight for them. 

It was the same in the train. When I got to Clones I had to change trains. At Enniskillin I met my cousin Miss Kithy Gilmore at the Railway Station. She had no difficulty in picking me out. At Bundoim Junction I had to change trains again for Kesh where I arrived at 1. 30. My Uncle was on the platform and I picked him out at once from his resemblance to my mother. 

His house only about 5 minutes walk from the station down the line. I had a great ovation on arrival. They had killed the fatted calf in this case a fat duck, and I had an excellent dinner. In the afternoon I had a look around the farm crossed over river on the sleeping stones which have been there during the memory of the oldest inhabitants and of which I often heard

my mother speak of. I had a good view from the top of a hill of Loch Gorn and saw the Bow Island . Lock Gorm is a large lake stretching to Enniskillen 12 miles away and beyond that there is Upper Lock Gorm. Enniskillin lies between the two . It has about 5000 inhabitants.
Entry.62:
The next morning I had a look at the village of Kesh and got some Post card views . I also had a look through the Kesh Busher Factory . The manager Mr. Gibson showed me all the workings. In the afternoon with Uncle we took the train to Pettigo 4 miles away and from there walked 3 miles out to Anneslan to see my Aunt Maggie Mrs James Martin. It was a surprise visit as they did not know I was in Ireland. They were delighted to see me and in the evening they drove us back to Pettigo in an Irish Jaunting car. They are very comfortable to ride in. It was the first Jenting car I 

ever saw. The country at Anneselan is very hilly & from my Uncles house a good view can be obtained. Though the day was cloudy and threatening rain, I forgot to say that on Friday night Mrs Muldoon & her husband and Mrs Riley and her husband came to see me. And on Saturday night Kithy Gilmore came from Enniskillen.
Entry.63:
A showery day nevertheless Kithy and I walked to Crevenish Castle in the morning . We met Mr Gibson and he came with us. We saw the Spa well and tasted the water, which has a very unpleasant smell, being strongly impregnated with sulphur and other minerals, but tastes all right. It is regarded in the district as a cure for sore throats. 

The castle is in ruins and covered with ivery the roots of which have penetrated through the walls causing them to crack in all directions. The castle is 3 or 4 stories high, but the roof and all the floors have rotted away, and there is nothing but the bare

walls standing . There are in the walls loop holes or narrow slits which do duty for windows. It is or rather was surrounded by a wall and doubtless this castle was the scene of many a fierce battle in the olden times. There is a cemetery adjoining the castle, the tombstones are laid flat over the graves, they bear various coats of arms and signs. One was a skull and a cross bone beneath it chiselled out of the stone. It is in an excellent state of preservation, but the lettering in most of the stones are not decipherable owing to moss and wear & tear of people walking over them. 

The Spa well is only a few chains from the castle and the overflow runs into Lock Gorn at the foot of the hill. The rubbet Island is facing the castle and the Lake here is about 9 miles wide, and extends past Kesh to Pettigo which is a rather pretty village, and contains a large mill driven by water power. 

On Sunday night in company with Mr. Andrew Muldoon I cycled over to Edriney 

to see Dr. John Patten with a view to getting my pass extended. As I had a cold he granted me 4 days extension of leave. Ederney is a larger village than Kesh, but as it was dark I could not see much of it. It is 3 irish miles from Kesh I was greatly deceived in Irish miles , as they are much longer than English miles. . 3 miles here is about equal to 4 english miles. We were an hour and a quarter away.
Entry.64:
A very wet day which continued all day almost constant. I walked over to Dromord to see my cousin Mrs Muldoon. Had dinner and then Mr Muldoon lent me his bike and I rode over to Coolaness S. School about 3½ miles from Kesh to see Mrs Riley after dark I cycled into Irvinestown with Mrs Riley. I saw a number of public buildings including the R. C. Church, Orange Hall and the church of Ireland. The Orange Hall is between them. I obtained some post

card views of the place and had several drinks of the best Irish whiskey I ever tasted. When we returned we had a great cupper and some music. . I left at 10. 30 and cycled into Kesh which I reached after some delay caused by the chain coming off and slightly getting mixed in the roads. However I arrived safely at my Uncles, had a cup of cocoa and slept until 9. 30 when I came out for breakfast.
Entry.65:
Hallowe Eve. This is a well known day in Ireland and is a land mark in the seasons. The people doing their reckoning from this day . 

It was showery this morning . I caught the 12. 30 train from Kesh. My Uncle came almost to the station with me, and my cousin Lizzie Gilmore came in the train as far as Inniskillen . I stayed here for a few hours and we went to the Post Office where we were joined by Kithy Gilmore and they showed me

some of the sights of Enniskillen including the Lord Cole memorial on the hill which is surrounded by gardens and also the Town Hall and the convent. Then we had tea at Mrs Creswells. At 4. 45 the Belfast train started so we made our way to the station in good time. I gave each of my two cousins my tunic badges (rising suns and bade them farewell. I reached Belfast 8. 15 caught the boat in plenty of time by taking a tram a lady at the station red cross putting me on the right tram and also very kindly supplied me with a cup of tea and some bread and butter. About 9. 30 the steamer Duke of Cumberland started for Fleetwood. There were a great crowd of passengers and sailor and marines. We had to sleep on the "tween Deck . 

Going down the lock which is a long narrow neck of water stretching from Belfast to the open sea and lined on either side with wharfs and shipping we passed Harlands Wolfes ship building works. I saw here the newest warship

afloat H. M. S. Glorious just recently launched and built in Belfast. She has an enormous speed and is armed fore and aft with two 15 in guns. 

The river Logan runs into the lock . We were soon out of the Lock and in the open sea, and out of sight of the Emerald Isle of which I will have many pleasant recollections.
Entry.66:
The Duke of Cumberland arrived in Fleetwood about an hour before her usual time so we had a long wait before the Euston train started. A cup of tea and some meat pies were served out to the sailors & marines, and they did not forget the few soldiers aboard. 

We left Fleetwood about 6 a. m. I forgot to say that there was a fresh wind blowing, and our steamer pitched a good bit but I did not get sick. but felt very heavy owing to the foul tobacco air between decks. However I soon was alright when I got on the top deck and in the fresh air. We passed through some big towns on our way to London, such as

Nuneaton, Rugby and through one of the longest railway a tunnells in England – Kilsbury tunnel 5 miles long. 

We arrived at Euston a little before 1 o‘clock and I had dinner at the Red Cross Free Buffett E. R. S This is my third trip to London, but today it was raining nearly all the time and that made things miserable. At 3. 25 I boarded the train arriving at Salisbury at 5. 10 where I had to change trains and wait until 7 o‘clock for a train to Amesbury. I arrived in Amersbury at 8 . o‘clock walked out to the camp and reported to H. 2. office and was sent to the doctor to be examined. 

I forgot to say that from Euston I took the tube electric railway which is underground. In Euston Station I went down a lift, walked along several passages up a moving stairs and down another. Boarded the train and was whirled away to Charing Cross where I had to chain trains, there I took one that runs under the Thames to Waterloo railway station. As I had plenty of time I

Walked over to the Union Jack Club and wrote a letter to
Entry.67:
A dull cloudy day but fine,

I am at the same old routine work again. Measuring mules feet this morning. 22 draught mules came into the stables last night . Most of them are quiet, but there are a few rough ones. 

I am anxious to hear the result of being A. W. L. for 3 days. A lot will depend on what the Battalion doctor says

I wrote a long letter to my wife describing my trip to Ireland & the first day there. 42.
Entry.68:
A very wet dirty day

Mathews & I were shoeing in the morning, and we had practically nothing to do in the evening. 

At or about 2 O‘clock I was paraded before the colonel, accompanied by the warrant officer from Head Quarter Sergeant Robinson & two R. P. to answer a charge of being A. W. L. for 3 days on my recent visit to Ireland. As I had a doctors certificate signed by Dr. John Patton of Edinery

And had a very good record. I was let off with 7 days C. B that is confined to camp. I answered the first call at 6. 30 together with others. There were 4 calls in all the last at 9 o‘clock.
Entry.69:
A much better day but cloudy. I was clipping horses in the morning, and in the afternoon stayed in camp writing letters, and also in anticipation of the Defaulters call being blown on the Bugle and C. B. s have got to answer it whenever blown. It is liable to be blown on any Saturday afternoon. I wrote a long letter to Willie 7 pages describing my trip to Ireland 

There were only two defaulters calls tonight because it was so wet. I also sent to my wife 1 packet of 33 postcards mostly of Ireland & 6 cigarette cards. 

There will be a general mobilization of the whole Brigade tomorrow and preparations were made

tonight . Web equipment put together and instructions given for the rolling of blankets etc in the morning.
Entry.70:
A very wet day. Continuous rain all the morning. 

The mobilization Inspection took place in the huts owing to the heavy rain. I was helping the pioneers and got my feet & legs wet through. I sent H G Kittson 3 London weeklies. 

I received two letters from my wife today. No 15 dated Sept. 10 and No 16 dated Sept 17. I sent to my wife a book "The Travellers Guide to Life" which my aunt Mrs John Gilmore gave to me when I was in Kesh Ireland visiting her. 

There were some wattle blossoms in each of the letters I got from my wife today showng that there is an eary spring at Merino, Victoria
Entry.71:
Fine with a few light showers. 

There was a general mobilization parade of the Transports today before the Bridiger General & Col Woods. I with the other two farriers had to parade in full marching order

and load a horse each. It only occupied less than half an hour. In the evening we were clipping horses.
Entry.72: Cloudy with occasional showers. Clipping horses in the morning and also in the evening. Sargeant Mc Nicol was in charge of the defaulters calls tonight.
Entry.73:
A general mobilization of the whole Battalion and an inspection by Bridiger General Mc Nicol in the afternoon. The dress was full marching order with everything we are taking to the front packed in the pack. Blankets were rolled up and packed ready for transport, and the boards and surplus blankets stacked in the huts. The kit bags filled with the clothes & other things that are not to go with us were also stacked,

I saw in the paper this evening that the S. S. Arabic was torpored in the Meditterian Sea and that the passengers were saved but 2 engineers are missing. She had on board the Australian mail and presumably it is all lost. I got two copies of the Argus Aug 25 & 26 today from Aus . {?}
Entry.74:
A cloudy day, cold & frosty last night and this morning. I was clipping horses all day. 

I finished the 7 day C. B. to night and answered all the defaulters calls. It was a cheap price for the 3 days extra leave I took when in Ireland. There were from 3 to 4 calls every night. And the distance from my hut No 20 to the Battalion office is about yards so that would make from yds to 8 yards I had to go every night. Some nights when I did not hear the first call I had to go at top speed especially one night I went to the Y. M. C. A. to post a letter & when coming back I heard the call & had to run about a quarter of a mile, & was at the office in time

I posted a Christmas card to my wife tonight. 44.
Entry.75: Cold & frosty and cloudy . Clipping horses all day. I wrote a long letter to my wife tonight
Entry.76:
A fine day for a wonder. We were branding horses this morning. This afternoon I walked into Amersbury to get my photo taken, but the two photographers

had such a rush of work they could not do it and had to turn a lot away. I was delightfully surprised to get another letter from my wife today. No. 17. and dated September 24. 

Tonight the pioneers were issued with new rifles at 7 o‘clock. The number of my rifle is C. 4941 we were also issued with a Bayonet, oil bottle and pull through.
Entry.77:
There was a general mobilization of the whole Battalion this morning Mathews & myself marched with the transports and led a couple of horses each. 

Early in the week I sent to John Bull Newpapers ,London for two Fountain pens. They arrived today. One I got for C. Cunningham. 

I sent Mr. J Murphy of Merrigum a P. C. of the R. C. Church at Irvinestown. 

 Monday November 13. 1916 

A beautiful day with nice warm sunshine in the afternoon. 

There was a general mobilization of the 3 division

This morning, comprising the 9th. 10th &
Entry.78:
Brigades for a 15 mile route march as a test of endurance & fitness. The 37 Battalion formed up at 9 o‘clock on the Parade Ground the Pioneers leading, and were joined on the way by the 38. 39. and 40 Battalions. The other 2 Brigades also joined up. The whole procession was about 14 miles long. The longest I was ever in I cannot say it the longest I ever saw for it was impossible to see either end of it. 

We marched through Amesbury, Stonehenge, Shrewton, passed the sausage balloon, near Bustard and from there home to camp. It was the most strenuous march I ever experienced and the longest since I have been in the army. Many fell out on the way and had to report to the doctor at the rear of their own battalion. Some fell out when we were only a few miles on the march and others all along the route until we were near home. 2 of the pioneers, Jorgensen and Holland. We were in full marching order carrying all our things, with the exception of blankets) & the rifle. Our

shoulders were sore with the weight of the pack and the rifle. When I got back to camp I had a bath changed my clothes both shirts being saturated with perspiration & put on fresh ones. There was only 20 minutes for dinner and very few spells. It was really a forced march.
Entry.79:
Cold & foggy today especially in the evening. I shod the Bridigers horse this evening. 

I wrote to my wife tonight enclosing 3. Badges Post cards. 47.
Entry.80: Cool and cloudy all day. The pioneers attended a booming class today, and had practise in throwing dead bombs and a very interesting lecture on explosives and the Mills Hand Grenade by Maj. Toule.
Entry.81:
A cold bleak wind blowing all day from the East. 

In the morning the Pioneers had practice in throwing live bombs – Mills Hand Grenade. In the afternoon I was shoeing.
Entry.82:
A bitterly cold and bleak wind blowing all

day . This morning I shod a Brigade hack No 46, size 3. And another in the afternoon A. 3. shoe size 7.
Entry.83:
l916

There was a light fall of snow last night and again this afternoon & tonight. 

There was an inspection of the Brigade and Battalion horses this morning. After the inspection I shod the Brigaders chestnut horse this morning . After dinner the pioneers were instructed for 2 hours in bayonet exercise. 

At 4 oclock I walked to the Amesbury Railway Station and sent away to my cousin in Ireland a parcel containing 1 pairs of breeches, 1 pair of drawers and a drill book and a few other little things for safe keeping. I wrote to Lizzie Gilmore tonight enclosing a Christmas Card. 

I sent a New Year Card to my wife tonight and wrote on it several verses of poetry. 

While in Amesbury I was in a stationers shop. It is also a general shop and is kept by Soul Bros. It is a very old shop and Mr Soul showed me a 

fireplace that is 500 years old and gave me a postcard of it. I bought several post cards & Christmas cards and sent them away from there. It snowed all the way 

when I was coming back from Amesbury. 

Today we were issued with 1 extra blanket. 1 ration bag, 1 small tin rifle oil,1 pair of black boots, 1 pair of drawers, 1 pair of socks, 1 singlet. 1 cake soap, 1 steel helmet.
Entry.84:
It snowed all last night and this morning, and it looks as if it is going to continue this evening. This morning despite the falling snow the Pioneers with a detachment from all the companies were sent out to the ranges for instruction in the Lewis Machine Gun. 

I wrote to my wife today letter 48

I wrote to my aunt Mrs. James Martin, Annesclan, Pettigo. Ireland. Xmas and I wrote to Father a long letter enclosing a xmas card. I sent a postcard of "The Spreading Chestnut Tree" to John Cooper & Sons. I sent a packet of post cards to my wife tonight

We packed up our packs tonight with one blanket inside and the other wrapped in the water proof sheet bent round the pack in horse collar fashion.
Entry.85:
There was a lot of drizzling rain last night which melted the snow except the large boulders of snow that were rolled together by the lads. 

There was an inspection of packs this morning. All English blankets, boards, treshels and tables were stacked in heaps and carted away tonight. We have only our two issue blankets to sleep in tonight. I was shoeing this morning, and in the afternoon branding Brigade mules and 2 horses. 

Tonight we were issued with 80 rounds of ammunition and a leather jacket. We expect to go tomorrow night.
Entry.86:
Dull and cloudy this morning. I was helping Mathews to brand transport horses and mules in the morning and in the afternoon I shod a Brigade horse A. 7

While we were at the Post Office

on our return from the forge this morning a military funeral passed with short step and slow. The coffin was on a gun carriage and decorated with flowers. An Australian band led the procession, but it was all Englishmen soldiers that followed the gun carriage. 

I slept in my clothes last night without any blankets on the floor rather than pull my pack to pieces. 

Saw Joe Carr – a student last night. He is in the 30 Battery 8 field artillery Brigade, 3 Division. He is a driver I often see Dolly Varden. I hear that Jack Brake is on Salisbury Plains and that he is now a Lieutenant. The whole battalion paraded this afternoon for instructions in embarkations and allotment of men to the different trains. It takes 3 trains to bring the Battalion I am in the 3rd train
Entry.87:
A fine day there was a slight frost last night. I gave away to 2 tommies last night some things I could not carry. 

The first and second lots got away in good time this morning. The Pioneers are to go in the third train

with D. company. I was helping the transports to get packed up this morning. 

We left Lark Hill a little after 12 and marched into Amesbury carrying everything with us. We were at the station in good time and left about 2 p. m. and arrived at Southampton about 5 o‘clock and after some delay went on board a small but fast steamer named the King Edward. We had some lunch in the train and also on board. We steamed out about 6 and arrived at a French port about 1 a. m. in the morning . The port was Havre.
Entry.88:
1916\It was a fine morning and we were up early and had breakfast on tinned corned beef and biscuits served out to us last night. Those who could get it had tea, the supply running out before we were all served. A few were sick, last night including our sargeant and N. J. Jorgensen,of the pioneers. There were on board a company of the 38 Battalion. There were 2 other steamers to take over the balance of out Battalion. Havre is like an English port. And there are a lot of English vessels in the Harbour which is well sheltered one. 

We went ashore early in the 

morning after a scanty breakfast and had a long weary march along wharves across brides and through long winding streets to No. 1 camp on the top of the Hill. We had several stoppages on the way and eat our lunch about 10. 30 on the side of one of the main streets. We were surrounded by swarms of French boys & girls , most of whom could speak enough English to ask for "Biscuit, pennies, cigarette" We were sold oranges for a 1d each. We passed many fine buildings 4,5 and even 6 stories high and some fine churches, in front of one was a large open space on which we rested for 20 minutes or so. The streets wound along the side of the hill to the top, in a very steep grade. One of the streets has been renamed Ave Edith Cavelli and another at the camp Ave Kitchener. We reached the camp at 1. 30 and had some tea & something to eat . We were too tired to have much of a look round but I went to the Y. M. C. A. & bought tobacco & biscuits. We had a late tea & got to bed early.
Entry.89:
We were up early this morning had a breakfast of hot stew 

before daylight and marched to the railway station by a different and much shorter route by which we came. – the distance was about 2 miles downhill, a vast difference to the 5 mile uphill march of yesterday. 

We were on board the train about 8. 30 and were put into cattle trucks without any seats. We had a long wait for the train did not start until 10. 45 and we had to draw supplies for the day and had a dixie of tea and bread & butter at a stand close by, for which a small charge was made. The cattle trucks were rather rough to ride in, but we soon became used to it. was our first stopping place, and as we journed south we passed through some beautiful country and many fine towns. 

Porvein was the largest and most important. It is built in a valley among the hills. There are many fine gardens around Porven and judging by the of small chimleys many factories. I had 6 feeds today . consisting of cheese French bread tinned beef & biscuits & jam
Entry.90: We travelled nearly all last night sleeping in the cattle truck as best we could. We had breakfast at daylight. I made a drink of hot soup. We reached Etaples this morning at 9. 30 which is on a river & is of considerable size, after dark about 6 we arrived at a large railway station called Balerple where we got out and was transferred to a covered in ushor lorry 30 men with their kits to each lorry. After an hours journey we arrived at our destination, and were quarted in billets for the night, on ground that had early in the war been fought over. We did not get into the billets without considerable delay caused by men loosing their kits and getting others. I was fortunate and stuck to mine all through.
Entry.91:
It was 10. 30 before we had breakfast, and then we had to go to B. company to get it. At 3. 0‘clock there was a church parade. 

Last night and this morning we could hear the booming of the big guns in the distance. In the evening we saw a German areoplane and the

allies shelled it but without result. We could easily see the smoke of the bursting shells around the areoplane.
Entry.92:
We were up late this morning. All the Headquarters are in our billets and we are very busy cleaning it up and making it fit to live in. These came in 27 bags of parcels & some letters from Australia this morning. Some of the Pioneers got parcels but I did not. 

I wrote to Kithy Gilmore and to my wife this evening. 50. 

Later. I got 3 letters from my wife to night dated Oct. 11. 10 &11 also a letter from Willis Oct 11 & one from I. Ring.
Entry.93:
We left our billets here at 8 o‘clock, formed up on the road and marched 13 miles carrying everything with us with the exception of the Blankets which went in the transports. We marched through several towns and villages until we came to Armienetries where we were billeted in a large convent almost every window of which was broken. The Pioneers were put on the second floor of one of the wings. There were several churches attached to the

convent and they all bore traces of shells as well as the convent. In the march we passed a large church in a town next to Armieneteries that was badly knocked about by shellfire – one end being blown clean out. All the buildings about here are of brick. 

There are many shops open generally all fancy goods chocolates and soldiers requisities, With 2 others I got a bottle of wine for 2 franks and we enjoyed it.
Entry.94: We were up early but had a late breakfast. Then Mathews and I were sent to look for the transports about 1½ miles away, we were tired but we walked round for several hours, without success and on our way back we came across them by a fluke. There were only about half a mile from our camp at the square.
Entry.95:
Mathews and I reported again to the Transport Sergeant, and were set to, to unload a waggon of tools & pack them in a heap. Before the war I am

told there was a population of 35,000 in Armeneteries but now it is only about 5,000. There are hundreds of empty shops with the windows broken and the goods looted. 

In the afternoon all the Pioneers were marched from our billets in the convent at half past Eleven Square to another part of Armenetiers called Houplines about 2 miles away and put in billets about 1200 yards from the German lines. We are in a large 3 storied house I am on the second story in a nice little room with a stove in it. 

There are two New Zealand Pioneers in it but they will be removing in a few days. I have a fine French Spring bed to sleep on, and on which I have already spread my waterproof sheet, 2 blankets and overcoat. It is the first nights comfort since I have been in France and the fourth place I have camped at. The only draw back is that my sleep is liable to be disturbed for the German machine gun bullets often play on the walls at night and at street crossings we have been warned to be careful in

crossing at night for the spit of the bullets can be heard and the flash seen as they strike the hard cobbled paved streets. As no food was sent down for us the N. Zealand Pioneers invited us to tea, which we heartily enjoyed and I went to bed early for I was very tired & foot sore.
Entry.96: How the time flies & the year will soon be out, and I have been a soldier since Feb. 28. Well it is a hard life and I would not again adopt a soldiers life from choice and yet those in the trenches have a far worse time of it. We are settled down in our new billet and like it very well. We have been making periscopes this morning for those in the trenches. Already some of our Battalion have been taken out of the trenches wounded and others sick.
Entry.97: Cold and frosty all day. I done a little Blacksmithing today; made a new D. for lock of tool chest. The New Zealand Pioneers removed from here this evening. Those of our Pioneers who were upstairs have gone below. I am now the only one upstairs in this part of the House.
Entry.98:
Cold and frosty; much more so than yesterday. We are making more perescopes for the boys in the trenches. The wood and the silvered glass we obtain from mirrors and over mantles in the abandoned houses about here. It seems a pity to cut them up but there is nothing else for it. The people have evidently left their homes in great haste for the furniture, pictures, ornaments, cups & saucers , knifes and forks are in the houses. They come in very handy for us. 

I wrote to my wife today - letter 51. I also answered Iriene Ring‘s letter yesterday. Tonight I was guard with another pioneer over supplies at D. company’s dump for about 2 hours. Stray bullets were whistling around. Tonight the Pioneers get an issue of tobacco, matches and cigarettes for the first time.
Entry.99:
A fine morning. I was down to the trenches this morning with perescopes for machine gunners at Head Quarters. I was very lucky this morning, receiving 3 letters dated Oct 13,16,,& 20. and a parcel containing a "Insto" self filling pen from 

my dear kind thoughtful wife. I am making these notes with the new pen. It was already filled with ink

This evening in the execution of my duty I saw another ruined church, practically totally destroyed, There was a large beautiful 3 storied house not far from it, evidently a Bishop‘s residence.
Entry.100:
Cold and cloudy . We are still making perescopes for the trenches. I have been making stencil plates today. I saw two men bought in dead from the trenches this morning. There are now casualties every day. I had a good look round a number of ruined houses looking for coke this morning. There were beautiful furniture in most of them but nearly all smashed up. They were evidently well to do people who lived in this part of the city of Armentieries or Houplines as it is called. All the houses I have been in have been looted & furniture smashed & valuables taken away. 

Tonight with B. Handcock I volunteered to carry a case of ammunition to the trenches. 

But it was more than we bargained for. We had to carry it about a mile through the trenches into the firing line at one place we had to get out of the trench & carry it along a tram line for about 70 yards with bullets whistling around us, and mud and slush e very where and then through more trenches. Coming back there was a gas alert and we put on our gas masks but fortunately no gas came our way.
Entry.101: At 12 o‘clock last night there was another gas alarm & again at 1 o‘clock. , but no gas came this way. I saw Harry Jones this morning on his way to the hospital . He has bronchitis and neuomonia. He just came out of the trenches after being in 4 days. I made & put in a chimley bar fitted with hooks in the Doctors room this evening. I got a dose of cough medicine from him.
Entry.102: Dull & cloudy and bitterly cold. The front is very quiet today. Last night I wrote to Willie and Cis. I have not been able to post any letters since we came here, until today.
Entry.103:
Dull & cloudy. We were at the usual work today also made a few wind vanes. 

I was up in the house last night, and again tonight.
Entry.104: A very dull & cloudy day. Not much work to do. The 39 Pioneers came in to our quarters today and we will be removing soon perhaps Monday. I have got my things packed ready to move.
Entry.105: There was a lot of drizzling rain last night, and it is cold and cloudy today. The 37. B. . — are now all out of the trenches and in billets. I was up in the city this afternoon, and bought a post card "Flowers of France" to send to Victoria. Parts of the city was shelled this evening. A shrapnel shell burst over a party of D. company outside their billets and 11 men were injured.
Entry.106: A fine morning. We moved out from this billet this morning to rooms a few doors lower down the street to make room for the new Pioneers. All day we were making things tidy. We cleaned out a room that had a lot of sand bags & planks in it, to make a kitchen. We put in a stove and got 4 chairs from abandoned houses.
Entry.107:
There was snow this morning when we got up & occasionally through the day . 

The Pioneers were resting today . We had practically nothing to do. 

I had a look through a priests house this evening. There was a small private chapel sadly in ruins, and the furniture of the house smashed.
Entry.108: Cold and cloudy today. The cold is very keen & penetrating this morning. We had very little to do today. The carpenters done a little work & I collected a lot of firewood. We had to stand to for an hour in case of an artillery attack.
Entry.109:
I got two letters from my wife last night. dated Oct 29 & numbered 28, & one numbered 29& of the same date with a cutting of the "Argus" containing conscription speeches. I also got another letter today number 26 & dated Oct 23. 1916

This morning we were detained to act as fatigue for the engineers who are
Entry.110:
Last night we were 3 hours in a shell proof ? room – from 5 to 8 as our artillery was bombarding Fritz, but he did not reply. Today we were

up at 5. 30 had breakfast and paraded at Little Mary dump to report to the engineers at 6. 15 We put on gum boots and went out into the front line of trenches to repair them . Our job was filling sandbags. We were only 60 yards from the German lines. But they left us alone. We had to walk through mud, slush & water to get to our work. Forgot to say that yestedday we had the gum boots on for the first time. They reach up to the thighs. The germans yesterday fired rifle grenades & many of them fell close to where we were working, but no one was hit. I saw one explode & it sent mud & dirt up to a great height & it fell in all directions. On another occasion a piece of shrapnel hit a tree alongside us. To day we were back from work at 12. 15. and the Sargeant & two cooks who were left behind, were not to be found. They afterwards turned up. 

Saturday December 16. 1916

Cold and frosty this morning . The 39 pioneers moved out this morning and we moved back in again to recommence our usual work. I have been writing letters this morning. I wrote to my wife. 53. and enclosed a P. card Flowers of France I received a letter last night from Kithy Martin Annerelan,Pettigo ,Ireland. 

I saw a copy of the "Daily 

Express" last night of the 14 inst and it was full of the German Chancellors Peace offer and the dire penalties threatened if the allies refuse peace. All the Neutral papers ridiculed Germany and regard the offer as a sign of weakness & that Germany is feeling the pinch & has no hope of winning by force of arms. The "Express" says the Kaiser is imitating Napoleon and to accept his officer now, would enable Germany to renew the war in a few years as Napoleon did in 1842 when his truce was accepted, only to be broken before the year was out

I saw one of the 39 Batt. carried in this morning badly wounded in the back near the shoulder. He was bandaged up but exposed to the cold. 

I received my second pay in France on the 14th. I was paid 40 Francs equal to £1-8-8. my first pay on the 5th inst was 15 Francs equal to 10/9. I was with C. F. Cunningham in the trenches for 2 hours 4 to 6, taking up a floor & bailing the water out of a dug out at Headquarters. . 

Sunday December 17. 1916

A very quiet day, scarcely any bombarding. The Pioneers were working all day making direction guides for the

trenches. I was drawing the letters and sign writing. We have a lot more to make tomorrow. 

Monday December,18. 1916 

It is only a week to Christmas, How the time flies? The year will soon be out, and I will be 10 months a soldier. It is almost mid-winter, and Christmas at hand. It is a new experience for Victorians Christmas in the winter, but ever since I have joined the army it has been a series of new experiences and most of them unpleasant , but there were a few pleasant ones which more than balances the rest. I do not regret joining the army, but will be glad when the war is over and still more glad when I get back to Victoria among my loved ones, and see my wife and mother again. Yet with all my longing to get back – and we have a song I want to get back- I do not wish to get back until Germany cruel treacherous Germany is thoroughly beaten and brought to her senses. I believe that happy day will not be long, probably in a few months time, perhaps early next summer. We were at carpenters work all day, flooring a dug out for ammunition. 

Tuesday Dec. 19. 1916. 

Very cold & frosty all day. In the afternoon, when we were in the trenches, it started snowing and continued until dark. Every night at the Engineers store we have been unloading the Transport waggons. To night we unloaded 7 waggons

Wednesday Dec. 20. 1916

Cold & frosty today. There are 6 of the Pioneers sick with dysentery , today . Some have been bad since Sunday. I wrote to my wife today letter 54. also to Miss Kithy Martin ,Iniselin Fermanagh. This morning I received a letter from Cis dated Oct 20. I should have received it a fortnight ago. 

This afternoon the sky is blue and clear, though the air is frosty. It is an ideal day for aeroplanes and as I write, I can hear our guns shelling, and see the shells bursting around an enemy aeroplane that flew over our lines into Villa de Houplines. With what result I do not know but I saw one enemy aeroplane hurriedly get away

Thursday Dec 21. 1916

We left our billets in Houplines before dinner and marched to the convent near the Half Past Eleven Square, and camped in a ground floor in a different part of the convent to where we were before. 

I had dinner in a French caffee, 2 eggs & chipps for 1/4d. We have only a little heating stove totally unfit for cooking. And we are served out with our own rations which means that we have got to cook them. More than half of the pioneers are sick with dysentery, or a mild form of ptomane poisoning. Some of them are vomating. I had only a very slight attack & no vomating. I did not have any tea, only a piece of dry bread. 

Friday Dec. 22. 1916

As we had no cooking arrangements. I had only bread & jam for breakfast. It is raining this morning – a cold & miserable day. A lot of the Pioneers are still sick , paraded sick but could not find the doctor so again paraded before dinner, I was not among those who paraded sick. This evening I bought an electric torch for 4½ Francs 3/9. 

I had tea outside tonight. Eggs & chips price 1½ frances 1/3d

Saturday December 23. 1916

It is showery this morning & yesterday I met Lieut Herring of Merrigum. He is in the 38 Batt. And looking very well. 

We are now getting the London papers regularly. The Daily Mail Chronicle, Express & the Mirror are sold by French boys in the street who can speak very good English, & come into the convent, or rather barracks as it now really is, every morning with the papers. These are all ½d papers in England but here we have to pay 2d for them. The Daily "Mail" heads a vigorous reply to President Wilsons Peace note to the Allies with this quotation from Wordsworth. . 

"We must be free or die who 

speak the tongue 

That Shakespeare spoke, the 

Faith & morals hold

Which Milton held. "

It also quotes with approval President Lincoln‘s reply to well meaning people who called for a premature peace during the American civil war. 

"The issue before us is distinct, simple, and inflexible. It is an issue which can only be tried by war and settled by victory. This war will cease on the part

of this Government whenever it shall have ceased on the part of those who began it…. We accept war rather than let the Nation perish. "

In that war Great Britain understood the gravity of the issue and steadfastly declined to intervene or to press on the United States ill – timed suggestions of peace. When another European Power did make such suggestion this was Mr. Seward‘s reply on behalf of Lincoln:

"This Government has not the least thought of relinquishing the trust which has been confided to it by the nation under the most solemn of all political sanctions, and if it had any such thoughts it would have still abundant reason to know that peace (so proposed) …. Would be immediately, unreservedly & indignantly rejected by the American People. "

That is our position today . We could not better these words: and as in 1862 they conveyed no discourtesy so they carry none now. "

"Daily Mail " Dec 22. 1916

I wrote to Cis to day. I also wrote to my wife letter 55 I also posted to her 2 post cards Verdun and a factory bombarded by the Huns, in a separate envelope. 

Sunday December 24. 1916

A nice day with beautiful clear sky. We are evidently going to get nice weather for Christmas. The sick Pioneers are much better today. J. R. Mathews had to report to the transport this morning for shoeing. 

In an adjoining catahedral St. Vaust, there was an R. C. military service for 5 soldiers at 9. 30. Part of the cathedral is in ruins from German shells but it can be easily repaired. Today with N. J. Jorgensen I had a walk through some of the principal streets of Armentieres, as far as the Y. M. C. A. and canteen situated in a large French college part of which is also used as barracks for troops. They are capable of accomodating over (shorthand). On the way we passed many fancy goods shops and all seemed to be doing a good trade with the soldiers. 

Tonight we received our Christmas parcels from the comforts fund in Victoria. My parcel contained a note from my wife dated Sept. 10. 1916. The parcel contained the following :-

1 tin chocolates

1 tin butter scotch

1 tin ham & chicken paste

1 tube tooth paste

1 tin Lucey Hinton tobacco

1 pipe

1 packet pipe cleaners
Entry.112:
pocket handkerchief. 

This is Christmas Eve but it does not look like it, There are very few signs of Christmas, except that the shops are doing a good trade and there was services in some of the churches. In the army the Christmas boxes reminded us of Christmas.
Entry.114:
Day:-

A fine day. We were up late his morning as we had nothing to do. We had breakfast of bread & fried bacon, cooked by ourselves, and some of the dainties out of the Christmas boxes from Australia. In addition to that we had a packet of Nestles chocolate from the colonel and a Christmas pudding for dinner. It was an excellent addition to the stew. 

In the morning I had 4 drinks of wine after breakfast at a neighbouring Estaminet with a soldier in B. compay. The landlady shouted cigars & a drink. Before dinner with the same soldier Sgt Major McFarlaine of A. company we drank 3

bottles of champagne costing 6 francs a bottle, that is 5/-. It was splendid and we thoroughly enjoyed it. After dinner with E. Handcock we went to the Y. M. C. A. in another part of Armntieres and enjoyed a free concert and a cup of tea and cakes. Coming home we had several drinks of French beer and wine, reaching home at 7. 30. Christmas day in France was very quiet, but on the whole I enjoyed myself occasionally we could hear our guns straffing the enemy in their trenches. In the morning a few aeroplanes were about, but our guns soon made them clear out.
Entry.115:
Boxing day. A fine day and not much doing. The sick Pioneers are now almost better. Our front was very quiet judging by the absence of noise. 

I bought a cigarette case this evening – a suvenier of Armentieres price 4 francs and 25 centimes. - 3/6½. In the evening 

There was a very good concert commencing at 5. 30 in the Y. M. C. A. but I did not go to it. Those who thoroughly enjoyed themselves.
Entry.116:
A dull cloudy morning but otherwise fine. I was not up until 8. 30. There was nothing to do, as we had another easy day. I went for a walk around the city in the morning with N. J. Jorgensen and saw many fine buildings and several factories whose tall chimley stacks were belching out smoke. We could hear the whir of machinery inside but could not get in. We also saw a church, or rather a cathedral that was badly damaged by shell fire. The spire was knocked off, the windows broken, and the roof badly damaged in places. We could not get in, but looking through a broken door we could see that the inside was badly damaged. 

In the afternoon we had another walk around in a different quarter of the city . We visited the Y. M. C. A. had a cup of tea and inspected a comparatively new church of modern design, and was touched by shellfire. Services are regularly held in . It was beautifully fitted up inside, The stations of the cross common to all catholic churches were

not pictures but bold relief in plaster beautiful executed there was also a model of a manger with the infant saviour Mary Joseph & the two shepperds on the platform near the alter. All the churches & large buildings in Armentieres are of brick set on stone or concrete foundations. 

When we got back to the billets about dark the Pioneers that were in had left for Houplines leaving a note behind to that effect. We had some hot stew that was in a dixie packed up our kits when the two handcocks turned up also Sgt. Robinson, and marched down to Houplines in the moonlight. As the 39 Pioneers had not moved out we camped in another room had some Australian cocoa and went to bed.
Entry.117:
It was very cold last night and when we got up this morning there was a thick white frost all over everything. 

We removed into our old rooms, as soon as the other pioneers moved out. This was all we had to do before dinner and I took the opportunity to do some writing and reading. 

I forgot to say that yesterday afternoon I bought another souvenir of Armentieres – a silver neck chain - in a shop at 56 Rue Sadi Garnot

opposite half past Eleven Square, and kept by the wife of a French soldier who is attached to out battalion as interperator – Georges Desercher.
Entry.118:
I got a letter from my dear wife last night dated Nov. 5 and numbered 29. also another this morning dated Nov. 12. and No. 31 & No 30 is not yet to hand . 

I was making wind vanes this morning, I was down in the trenches before dinner with a box of oil bottles to Head Quarters. . After dinner today there was a terrific bombardment by our artillery on the German lines. It is said that since Christmas, a new party of Germans – the Prussians – are in the Hun trenches, and we have no love for the Prussians. 

I wrote another letter to my wife today 57. I was on a new job this morning . I was in the drying room stoking three braziers to dry about 60 rain coats. The fuel was broken up furniture and pieces of old houses.
Entry.119:
A wet morning. There was a lot of rain last night. I was stoking the braziers in the drying room this morning to dry rain 

coats. The Germans sent over several shells before dinner, and one of them fell in the back room two doors from the drying room. Evidently the smoke attracted them. I then let the fires go out, as per orders. After dinner I was doing a little blacksmithing making pointers for the gas alarm. Tonight I had a hot bath in a tub, and a clean change of clothes, the first bath and change since I came to France. Afterwards I washed 3 shirts 1 pair socks and a pair of underpants.
Entry.120:
New Years Eve. 

The old year is nearly out and the war is not yet finished but prospects of its early & successful ending are bright. The past year has been a very trying one and a momentious one in the history of the world and in the lives of the individual units of the waring nations. 

I have been a soldier for over 10 months now and have seen many and varied sights and travelled half way round the world, and they are probably many more sights , some pleasant no doubt and others reeking of war in store for me. 

Our artillery gave Fritz a very severe straffing last 

night and again today at dinner time. No doubt they will fight the old year out and the New Year in. 

I got a letter from my wife this morning dated Nov18. No. 30. We were reveiting a trench today at the ammunition depot and when going to work after dinner 5 or 6 shells passed over out heads and landed near Port Arthur dump Those of the 39. who were in the vicinity were wounded. Our Artillery heavily shelled the German lines, putting in some hundreds of shells in quick succession. I watched them from the top of a trench and they ploughed through the enemies trenches throwing up mud, earth and timber to a great height. This was continuous all along the line, and systematic the shells dropping every half chain or so.
Entry.121:
New Years day on the front is not a pleasant one, for there are many sad surroundings, such as dead men and wounded ones also. I saw one soldier taken away this morning dead. 

I sincerely hope that I will be spending my next New Year in Victoria. 

together with my wife and friends. It will be a pleasant change from here away from the strife and storm of battle. I saw the Daily Chronicle this morning and judging by all accounts the war will be over early this coming Summer: There is heavy shelling of the enemies trenches by our artillery as I write, the boom of the guns shaking the building I am in. 

There was a raid by a section of our Brigade on the enemies trenches last night, but it was not successful. I hear that the raiding party could get no further than the barbed wire entanglements, which our artillery had failed to cut away. Artillery is the principal factor in this war and it will be won: and is being won by the artillery. Without preparation by the artillery the infantry has no hope. 

I paraded sick this morning & got some medicine for my colds & also to get my toe dressed. The nail is coming off it, caused by a horse tramping on it while at Romsey and the new boots I have got are too light. The only work I done this morning was to hang up some rain coats to dry. In the afternoon the Pioneers

were working in the trenches, repairing the sides near headquarters. We had a plum pudding for dinner today, - a gift from Australia, and there was ample for all and we enjoyed it very much. .
Entry.122:
A dull cloudy morning. Very like rain. About 10 o‘clock the sun shone out and it became bright and clear affording opportunities for snippers on both sides, a man in a working party of the Pioneer Battalion was shot through the head early this morning about 9. 00 we went down to the Head Quarters to finish repairing a trench. We were not there very long when the Boches sent over several shells falling very close to where we were working. One shell wounded a man in a working party of the 39 Battalion quite close to us and at a place where we were working a couple of days ago. As we could not finish our work, in fact I was ordered down off the bank of the trench where I was levelling a place for sand bags, we decided to go back to our billets until dinner time. 

We got another issue of tobacco this morning. I forgot to say that we all got a tin of lollies yesterday. We were not in the trenches this afternoon and done a few little odd jobs at the billets. C. Handcock and I carried down to Head Quarters two boxes of Veri Lights. 

The Germans continued to send over a lot of shells this evening, and as some of A. company were coming to tea caught the fire and 11 men suffered casualities. This was our unlucky day for the 37. Battalion. There was a total of 17 casualities for the day 5 of whom were killed, some of them being blown to pieces. Others suffered severe casualities.
Entry.123:
The 39 Pioneers came in this morning and we moved out into another room. Today is very dull and cloudy. Our artillery is harassing the German lines. The 37. Battalion moved out this morning. We helped to remove Head Quarters baggage from the trenches to their position in the billets. 

There was a terrific bombardment by our artillery tonight of the enemies lines. The Germans sent over a few tear shells. 

Our transport was down when the bombardment was on and they were in a terrific hurry to get away.
Entry.124:
A dull cloudy morning with some rain. The Germans last night with their shells caught some of the transports when they were returning to Armentieres. One man and two mules of the Pioneer Battalion transport were killed. Our artillery before dinner again severely bombarded the enemy. 

I got a copy of the "Argus" of Oct. 28. 1916 from my sister this morning. We are resting this morning as there is nothing for us to do. These notes are written with the "John Bull" fountain pen with tablets in dissolved in water.
