Between 12 and 1 today during the bombardment the Germans started to shell our billets. One shell burst behind out billet the concusion smashing the glass in the up stair window at which I was sitting reading the "Argus" Other shells fell each side and over. I thought it was time to go below. A few chains down the street in front of the Engineers depot a few shells fell

killing two men of a working party. One of them being Lieut. Bruce & was a South Melbourne footballer. I witness the explosion and went round the corner for the doctor, when told that some of the men were hit. The 39 doctor went to render aid and had a narrow escape as at least 2 more shells fell about the same place narrowly missing the motor ambulance which was on the scene when the shells fell the view was entirely blocked with smoke and brick dust & falling dust. A few gathered on the scene, when one of them was hit with a flying misile and ambled back into the engineers depot crying out they have got me . A piece of flying brick hit me on the side the face although I was fully 3 chains away. The Germans kept this up for some time landing their shells further over to get some of big guns in this vicinity. We got into a strong room but hunger drove us out to the kitchen for dinner. Needless to say there was no rush to the kitchen, and as each one got their stew they made back for the dugout or the street. While I was

in the kitchen a minney exploded out side . All had to help themselves as our cook was in the dugout. 

I heard today that the 40 Battalion had 39 casualities last night. While the 39 had none. Evidently the Boches have brought up some new guns for their fire is now more accurate numerous and continuous. This afternoon things have again assumed their usual quietness, except for the occasional booming of our guns. What makes our position so dangerous is that our artillery is placed behind us and are almost continually barking at the enemy. We are between the guns & the trenches and all shells friends & foe alike pass over our billets. If the Germans fall short they land in our billets.
Entry.125:
Things were very quiet last night. This morning is bright & clear and an artillery duel is expected. At 11 p. m. a few of our guns, as I am writing have started to speak at the enemy with no uncertain noise. 

Last night our transport had orders not to approach our lines with supplies as our billets were too dangerous. So we had to meet them further up the street, and carry our provisions down. 

We had a visit from our O. C. this morning Mr Toule, his visit was to read an order from Head Quarters relating to signals & telephone wires, and also to enquire if we got enough to eat. 

Interior of the Basilic after the bombardment. Guerre 1914-15

There was intermittent artillery activity this afternoon. Tonight the Pioneers were on a fatigue party to carry rations, fuel etc. for the 40 Battalion in the trenches. It was supposed to be only an hours work but it took 3 hours from 5 to 8 o‘clock. There trenches fortunately were very quiet, no shells or minnies landing only rifle and machine gun bullets. The 40 Battalion have suffered so many casualities that they are very short handed. Hence the reason for calling upon Headquarters details for a fatigue party.
Entry.126:
A dull cloudy day. There was a lot of rain last

night but it is fine this morning. The front is very quiet this morning. 

Before dinner we went up to Nieppe on the other side of Armentieres to the Baths. When we got there we found that we could not get in until 3 p. m. so we had dinner in the town at a neighbouring café, of chips & egg costing 1 franc & 30 centimes 1/3. Then we had a look at a cotton mill where they were weaving cloth stout calico and a kind of light canvas. It was a very interesting process to watch the looms at work each in charge of a man or a woman. The threads running lengthwise were all fixed on a roller which unwound more thread as required. The cross threads were runs akross by a large wooden shuttle that ran backwards and forwards by a being knocked at each end by a rocking arm. the threads being raised alternatively by an ingenious device. The machinery was made in England. 

At the baths we were casually examined by a doctor, and then proceeded to the Bath room. There there were large tubs of hot water 3 to 4 ft. deep and each capable of holding 12 men. Those who had dirty or worn out clothes got them changed. As mine were all clean & in good order I only exchanged my towel for a dry one. 

I heard yesterday that David McKean of B. company who accidently or otherwise shot himself in the foot was tried by Court Marshal and sentenced to 60 days field punishment.
Entry.127:
We were up about 6. a. m. this morning, had an early breakfast and proceeded to Waitangi dump and awaited instructions. We found that we were fatigue for the trench mortar Battery and with the stretcher bearers had to carry up 40 plum puddings 2 per man to the front line of trenches in the sector occupied by the 40 Battalion. The plum puddings weight about 50 lbs each consists of a big round ball filled with alemite and to which is attached a long iron spindle about 2ft x 2 in. to fit the mortar. 

We had a long weary tramp through the trenches to the front lines and in places where the trench is damaged had to walk at a stoop carring the missle in our arms. A few bullets whizzed over our heads at these low places and were unpleasantly close. Evidently the Germans saw us, As we could only carry one at a time, we had to make two trips of it. We were back early and got a cup of hot cocoa at the Brigade canteen This cocoa is ready every morning and is issued free. 

Yesterday I got the Portland "Observer" & the Hamilton "Spectator" supplement from my brother. Yesterday afternoon we were paraded to the Breweri (Brewery) to be paid. I was paid £1. 8. 8 40 francs in French money. 

We are always paid in French paper money. l got 4 ten franc notes.
Entry.128:
We were again up early this morning to act as a fatigue to the Trench Mortar 

Battery. We put on gum boots and assembled at the Waitangi dump. There were only 5 pioneers required . We drew lots who were to go

I was among those who had to go and carry trench mortar ammunition to the front lines. But in a different sector to yesterday. We had a worse road through mud and water. That part of the trench which goes through an orchard is badly knocked about. In some places it is completely blown away. As some of the fatigues disappeared after they had carried up the first one, the remainder had to go back again with more shells. All this time the germans were either shelling the billets, or the trenches contrary to their usual practice, they opened fire first thing before our artillery started. Usually they keep quiet if let alone. Our artillery took up the challenge and intermittent artillery activity continued all the forenoon up to dinner time. This morning was the most unpleasant time and also the most riskey that I ever had in the trenches. It was after eleven when I got back to the pioneer billets being the only pioneer who stuck to our job until it was completed. The others were already at the billets and said they got lost

the guide not knowing the way, and eventually disappeared. It is significant that the lost pioneers did not report at the ammunition dump when they got out of the trenches, but cleared off. The stretcher bearers and machine gunners constituted the remainder of the fatigue party. The machine gunners were game, particularly Fanagele, who showed not the least sign of fear. In fact he was fool hardy and took unnecessary risks . On our way back we had a cup of hot cocoa at the Brigade Canteen. 

This afternoon our bombardment continued of the German lines for several hours. Part of our Batttalion went back into the trenches today, the remainder goes in tomorrow and the 39 comes out. Already 2 of our men have been killed. 

We received our stored rations for two of our companies tonight. I saw Sgt. McNicol yesterday, It is the first time I have met him since I have been in France.
Entry.129:
A dull cloudy morning . The front is very quiet only a few shots to be heard. Again we carried up

ammuniation to the trench morters in the front line without any mishap, to L. section through Wessex Avenue. I was one of the lucky ones and only had one to carry up. Our Battalion went into the trenches this morning. After dinner the Pioneers had to remove H. Q. stuff from chatto row to the Battalion Head Quarter in the trenches . When we were coming back several shells fell near the two handcocks. 

The London papers of yesterdays date announce that the Portuguese are now in France with a strong force and after some training in modern trench warfare will go into action. 

I got a letter from cis last night dated Nov. 10. 1916. 

There was a terrific bombardment of the enemies lines by our artillery tonight soon after dark. The bombardment lasted about an hour and fully 1000 shells were fired. The Germans retaliated by throwing minnies into our trenches. The London papers of Sunday and of Monday announce the floatation of a new British loan of £500,000,000

the prospectus of which will be available next Thursday Jan 11th.
Entry.130:
A dull cloudy day. During the past few days the weather has been very cold and frosty both day and night. 

6 of the Pioneers last night had to get up in response to a call and go down to the front line of trenches and repair them where a shell had blown in the side blocking communication. I had not to go and knew nothing about it until this morning. 

This morning I saw one of the Dookie students named Williams. He is in the Engineers and has been in hospital lately. While there he met Harry Ryle the former gardner at Dookie college. 

This evening we had to carry up to Head Quarters 10 boxes of ammuniation, 10,000 rounds When we got half way we had to put the boxes down and turn back owing to the heavy straff that was going on. Later on we got them up without mishap. This afternoon there is intermittent artillery activity by our Batteries

At Chateau row - Battalion H. 2 when out of the trenches – a shell fell making a big hole 

in the ground and killing Captain Tyrell of the 40 Battalion, this morning.
Entry.131:
It is very cold and frosty here as a rule, but this morning there is a light fall of snow, and therefore the front is very quiet. But in clear weather it is almost continuous activity, with shells screeching overhead and sometimes bursting around us. Our work takes us everywhere sometimes in the fornt line of trenches, sometimes in the rear of the trenches but generally speaking the trenches are as safe as anywhere, It usually takes about an hour to go up to the front line and back, and when one has carried up a plum pudding weighing about ½ cwt, through winding tenches and frequently through mud and water up to the knees, he has got up a good sweat, and two trips is a good mornings work. Usually there is flying schrapnel and minnies, and whisbangs coming through the air, and they prevent loitering on the way. But we are not always on this kind of work. Our duties are variable and covers

everything from making crosses to shoeing horses and mules. We are soldiers , mechanics, repairers, engineers and labourers. The pioneers are expected to do everything and anything and so far have always come up to expectations. In the course of our duty we have had some narrow escapes but so far have been very lucky. We can usually hear the shells coming and generally have time to duck. It is when there are a number coming in quick succession and falling in all directions that the times are strenuous and puts the fear of God into the most hardened sinner, and the army has more than a fair share of callases and brazen sinners. 

This morning Jorgensen and I took up some parcels to Headquarters. When we came back all hands cleaned up the billets as an inspection by the Bridiger is expected. 

I wrote to Cis this morning
Entry.132:
A dull cloudy morning. There was a light fall of snow last night, and again this afternoon. It is exceedingly cold. There was very little

artillery activity last night and today. 

This afternoon were in the trenches fitting up a dug out in the side of a trench to store jars etc in. It got too late to complete it so we came back to our billets. Tonight our sector is very quiet but north of here towards Ypress there is a concentrated bombardment enormous in intensity and lasting several hours, followed by a great silence, as is usual after a gigantic bombardment, when hardly a shot is heard . During these periods of bombardment our heavy guns have thrown high explosive shells upon the enemy‘s positions previously registered as centres of traffic or as places where enemy working parties take advantage of the fog or the night. The results of the firing is not known at the time, but later our aeroplanes get up & can see the effects of these explosions, the destruction of strong points, the upheaval of gunpits, the flattened trenches, and the destruction of communications. But the awful casualities are not known. The distance and the fogs and mists prevents us taking toll of the dead and the wounded. 

The enemy strong in trench mortars, replies by concentrating this form of artillery upon short distance targits – our front line trenches & supports, but our strong arm of defense and attack our heavy artillery & he is powerless to injure or to silence. Fair weather or foul, the enemy has no rest and our guns are constantly hurling forth death and destruction. No wonder Germany wants peace. These sudden bombardments are often followed by a raid upon his trenches, quickly carried out. This makes him nervous, and he fires spasms of rifle & machine gun fire, for no reason except that of fear.
Entry.133:
A very dull morning, with cold sleety rain. Things are fairly quiet after the heavy bombardment last night, but tonight about 4. 30 it recommenced 

again but only continued for a little while. We had very little to do today. All I done was to carry up a box of Verie lights to Headquarters. 

I finished reading a book called "Hard Luck Hamilton" by Allen Dean. It is a capital story of hairbredth escapes and adventures of a famous footballer. It is interesting from start to finish. 

Only one transport limber came down tonight bringing rations only for headquarters as the company is going out tomorrow. Tonight about 9. a. m. our guns commenced a terrific bombardment of the German lines which lasted about half an hour.
Entry.134:
A cold frosty morning. The 37 Batt. came out of the trenches today & the 39 went in. The Pioneers moved out to day to Half Past Eleven Square to our old billets in the convent. I was 4 times down to the trenches this morning removing H. 2. Stuff and it was 2. O‘clock when I got to our billet and then I had to get dinner. 

It is exceedingly cold this evening. I saw by the papers today that the New War loan is a brilliant success and that the allies reply to Germany has created a very favourable impression in America. 

I got a letter today from my wife dated Nov. 26 No 33
Entry.135:
A cold morning but fine. There was no rain last night or today. We were all up very late about 8 o‘clock. We are supposed to be resting, nevertheless we expect to get some fatigue work to do. Today I bought a table centre 4½ francs and a cushion cover 22 francs and posted them to my wife through the shopkeeper who will get them censored and registered in the morning. The shopkeepers name and address was ;

A. Dervailly – Rolland

33 Rue de Dunkerque

Armentieres

The table centre was linen and the cushion cover silk costing in English £1-0-10. 

Before dinner I went up to the quarter masters store & got my boots 8/4 changed as they were too narrow for a size wider 8-5. 

We are to stay here until the 39 Battalion comes out of the trenches - then we are to go to a place called Steenwerck for a further period of training in bayonet drill & other specialities. I heard tonight that our Battalion has had about 100 casualities including 10 killed. I wrote to my Father tonight.
Entry.136:
a dull cloudy and misty morning. Very like rain. There was a little snow last night. We again had a very late breakfast this morning, between 8 & 9 o	‘clock. 

Head Quarters details got paid this morning. I was paid 40 francs in two 20 franc notes. £1-8-8 in English money. To our great surprise we got a packet of
Entry.137:
presents, marked "With Christmas Greetings from Citizens War Chest Fund N. S. Wales Division of the Australian Comforts Funds. A. I. F. 1916. B. E. F. 

The box contained two packets of Barratt & Co‘s Peppermint Bulls‘ Eyes lollies, 1 packet spearmint, 1 pipe, 1 tube toothpaste, 1 tooth brush, two boxes matches ,1 match box case, writing paper and envelopes, & our Australian comic Post cards 2 kharki handkerchiefs, and two packets cigarettes. 

Tonight I received a letter from Miss Irene Ring dated Nov 19 I sent her a post card "Souvenir of France" I also received another letter from my wife dated Nov. 24 and numbered 32. and sent her a silk post card in answer. I also sent a silk P. C. to my mother and another to Cis. I also sent a P. C to

Eileen Ring (Nel)

Marionvale school

Victoria. "Souvenir de France"

Wednesday Jan 17. 1917. 

It is snowing this morning. There is 3 or 4 in of snow on the ground. I sent a post card to my little niece. Maggie Hittson "The Cross of the Allies" I also

sent a Post Card to my Father. "The Star of the Allies. " That is 7 silk post cards in all. 

Today I received a copy of the Portland Observer dated Nov. 9. 1916. giving a report of the Exemption Court held at Portland. 

There has been very light fall of snow all day until about 4 o‘clock when it was almost imperceptable. I bough a silver neck chain & a small cross for my wife today from Georges Devarcher 56 Rue Sadi Garnot Armentieres, price 6 

Tonight I signed an army form for a new book to be issued in 8 parts and entitled "Australia in the Great War" price 5/- The Publicity Department of the High Commissioner‘s Office will make arrangements for the packing and posting of each part to my wife.
Entry.138:
We were up about 5. 30 this morning, had an early breakfast & were ready to march off at 7 o‘clock. The trasnsports carried our packs. Our blankets we carried horse collar fashion. We marched away from Armentieres, across the bridge over the river Lys, passed

the baths, through Nieppe and to the rest camp near Steenwerck. Before we got to the camp we had a long weary wait on the road to allow other Australian soldiers to move out. We reached the camp easily before dinner which was stew cooked by the H. 2. cooks. It was inferior to our own cooking. 

The Colonel who has been away indisposed, turned up at the camp at dinner time. Last night several of the pioneers had a gay time at one of the Estaments drinking French bottled beer at 6d per bottle. It is a great improvement on the draft beer. 

As J. R. Mathews is now on the strengtrh of the transport, a new man was put in his place, Earnest Carter, he came over in the third reinforcements.
Entry.139:
We slept very comfortable & warm in the huts last night. They are like a round tank on its side being constructed out of curved galvanized iron which serves for sides & roof. They are about 18 ft wide 30 ft

long. They would hold 25 mean. There are 20 in our hut. 11 pioneers and 9 sanitarymen including their corporal. Too good. 

No one can go out of this camp without a pas and we must be in not later than 9. 30. Three of us were out last night. We went to an Estanment on the cross roads to Steenwerck and had a few drinks. Todoay we put up a new cook house for the officers mess, and pulled down the old one. It is only a small affair 4 posts in the ground, curved iron for a roof, and lining boards for sides.
Entry.140:
There was a very heavy frost last night. The mud is all frozen hard on top , and there is ice on the water in the drains. It is much better than the mud and slush. 

The pioneers had a new experience last night. The new recruit Carver, went out early in the evening and came home late very drunk and quarrelsome. He first started in the Sanitary section, and then started reciting a doggrel rymes. We counted him out whereupon he turned

upon the pioneers and praised the Sanitary Section. He talked for a long while when suddenly he warned the Sargeant that he was going to be sick, and was subject to fits. He wanted to get up and was helped outside and immediately had a fit on the duck board. When he came to he was carried inside and had 4 more. The doctor was sent for, gave him some medicine and wanted to know what he had been drinking. He replied "coffee". He was so bad that the doctor ordered him to be sent to the hospitale. Before he went he made his will in his pay book, the sergeant writing it out for him. I believe he is to be removed from the pioneers as he is no use to us. He had an operation performed upon his head, is fond of the drink and is subject to fits. 

Today we could hear the big guns booming in the distance. We had not much work to do today, a little carpenters work and repairing duck boards.
Entry.141:
It was very cold and frosty last night. The mud is now frozen hard. I got a letter from Kithy Gilmore last night and 2 fresh papers. I also got a letter from my wife today dated Dec 1. And written from the Lakes. They have a good season there and at the time of writing there were hot winds. 

This morning we put up a new latren for the officers with an iron roof and canvas sides. Tonight I got a pas and went out and had a feed of beefstake, eggs and chips costing 2 francs and 2 ct.
Entry.142:
Cold and frosty last night, but otherwise fine. There was heavy artillery straffing of the enemy last night. The boom of the big guns could be heard and their flashes in the sky could be seen from this camp. 

Louis Raemackers the Dutch cartoonist writes in the weekly dispatch of yesterdays date expressing his fears of a German invasion of Holland by way of Flanders in quest of good stuffs, and in the hope

of gaining another strategic victory and using the dutch ports as submarine bases 

for an attack upon England. The dutch are well prepared and have a number of 420 millimetre (16¾) guns held in readiness on the frontier near Maastricht. 

This afternoon there was a prolonged artillery activity of the enemies position, within hearing of this camp. This evening Private Knox from Dookie received a letter telling him that Paddy Shelton one of the farmers on the college died from wounds received in France.
Entry.143:
There was a very heavy frost last night and this morning the ice on the drain where we wash will bear the weight of a man on it without breaking. The heavy straffing of the enemies lines by our artillery continued last night until a late hour. 

There are several rumours about today. One is that part of Hoaplines has been shelled by the enemy and that Wessex Avenue has been partially destroyed and the German front line trenches blown out of existence and prisoners

captured. Also that the Colonel and a number of officers of the 36 were killed in the trenches by a shell. 

I got a copy of the Weekly Times from my father yesterday
Entry.144:
There was another keen frost last night. The ice is now strong enough to walk on it on any of the drains. It is now 236 days since I left Seymour camp, the day we left and today inclusive. My deferred pay now amounts to £11=16=0. I have drawn £14"19"9 up to the last pay day, including 10/- from the Romsey school of Farriery, and 15/- forfeiture A. W. L. 

Today is nice and bright and there are a number of aeroplanes about, and this afternoon the guns can be distinctly heard, bombarding the enemy. We were shifted from our hut in the third line to No 6 hut in the first line. 

President Wilson in a speech to the Senate formulated his views on the war and the terms of peace. He thinks there should be no victory. The London papers do not agree with him, and think that Germany should be put in such a position that she

will not again be a menace to the world. Peace without victory, would leave the old Germany on an equality with the allies, whereas we want a new and humbler Germany with loftier and saner views.
Entry.145:
For the past few days there has been presisent rumours out our Colonel leaving us and going back to Australia owing to indisposition. Yesterday after dinner he left here to go to England. He has insomnia and bronchitis and although he is a very big man, it appears that he is not a robust man. I hope he will soon get better and come back to our battalion, for although he had his faults his bark was always worse than his bite. We might get a lot worse, He was a capable man and a fair man. He was outwardly rough and very stern but had a kind heart. 

Last night Headquarters details were paid by Lieut -----. I received one 20 franc note 14/4 in English money. We were also issued with pallaises which we filled with straw. It is a 

great improvement on the loose straw as we can keep out huts cleaner. As it is our hut gets dirty enough for we use it as a work shop and also eating room, as well as bed room and living room. There was another severe frost last night. The ice is over 3 inches thick on the drains, and there is not a trace of mud to be seen anywhere. Everything is frozen hard and solid and the roads and ground have every appearance as if it was the middle of a hot summer. The rattle of vehicles can now be heard where a week ago the roads were a quagmire. The intense cold has made a wonderful transformation on the whole landscape. Canals, ponds and drains are now skating rinks and one can walk about anywhere dry shod. Our boys often go skating and there has been many falls on the slippery ice one fellow getting a broken arm and another a broken nose. 

Today we painted the wheels and wood work of the water carts and cookers with wood preserving oil, while the carpenters were

Busy making latieen seat and fitting up a canteen. 

All day long from early morning until late in the evening French girls are on the road and on the edge of the lines selling chocolates hot buns and lollies to the troops. They seem to take no notice of the cold but of course are well wrapped up. French boys are in the lines at breakfast time selling the ½d London papers. They charge 2d for them and they are a day old. 

Our doctor Captain Yule went away a few days ago to a base hospital to get a share of the practice and experience to be obtained there. He is relieved by captain
Entry.146:
Exceedingly cold and frosty last night and today. General Semack inspected us today, He was accompanied by the Bridiger. Soon after we got instructions to pack up. Fold our blankets in marching order ready to move. We had a hasty dinner and got ready. As I had very sore feet I was put on the baggage guard so as to get

a ride. By tea time we had no instructions when to move, so we had tea. The Lewis gunners & bommers had moved off early in the evening & there was a rumour that we had to relieve another battalion in the trenches at 12 o‘clock. During all this time my feet were getting worse & I could not stand on my right foot after tea. So the Sargeant had me carried to the doctor, who prescribed whale oil, as it was a case of trench feet. C. Handcock was put on the baggage guard. Instruction came through that we were to move off at 9 o‘clock. As my foot was now badly swollen the pain intense & I could not get the boot on, the Sargeant saw the doctor, & he decided to send me to the hospitle. About 8. 30 the motor ambulance arrived and with two others I was taken to the hospitle at Steenwerck when I got there I had a long wait in the receiving room before being taken to the ward & put in bed D27. My feet were dressed with whale oil and wrapped in cotton wool. 

When I was I the receiving room a man was brought in whom the driver of another van found on the road. He was badly cut about the head and had been missing

all day from A. company. He was dressed & bandaged later on when taken into the ward.
Entry.147:
I feel much better today my feet are not so painful. I am in bed all day and was given a small bottle of Guiness Stout at dinner time. 

Today is the Kaiser‘s birthday & according to the papers there will be no celebration in germany. And a dinner in honour of the occasion in Berlin will consist of the usual ration allowance, no wine will be permitted only beer. It will be a very sombre affair in accordance with the prevailing distress and misery there. 

There is a gramophone in this ward, and it has been going all the afternoon . Most of the patients in this ward have trench feet.
Entry.148:
Very cold & frosty all day. The sky is clear & bright. My feet are much better and I rub them with whale oil 3 or 4 times a day. Of course I am in bed, as rest is essential to a cure. 

I saw one of the 11th field ambulance men who came on board the Ferrie at Cape Town. He is in this hospitle with sore

feet but goes out this evening to his own hospitle. He was fined £2 and 7 days detention for missing his units boat at Cape Town. 

Near this hospitle there are a number of anti air craft guns. Yesterday they got 2 german aeroplanes one fell near Armentieries.
Entry.149:
The cold last night was arctic in severity. Some nights 20 degrees of frost have been registered. Today is fine but intensely cold. . This morning 13 patients were discharged or transferred to other places from this hospitle which is known as the 3rd Division Rest Station A. I. F. 

A platform was rigged up in one corner of this ward and a concert held this afternoon. The programme was a good one and consisted of songs, duets, pianoforte selections and ventriloquism. The officers were present & the chief M. O. was chairman. 

The cold weather makes us all eat well,& we are always ready for our meals. I had a bottle of Irish stout for dinner today
Entry.150:
The cold wave continues, the "Daily Mail" says all

Europe is in the grip of the front, & the weather has been the most continuously cold & severe for 22 years, and the bitter East wind chill persists. In Holland the waterways are blocked with ice. A number of Danish & Swedish harbours in the Cattegat & Baltic are ice bound. The Southern end of the Sound was completely frozen over. The Paris canals are covered with ice 1 in thick. An icy Eastern gale swept over th Eastern Counties of England freezing up the ponds & rivers and driving the wild fowl inland. The swans left the frozen waters & sought food at the houses. The lakes in the London Parks were frozen over & skating the first time for 5 years was prevalent. The greatest snow storm known for 25 years swept over Ireland being particularly severe in the West & centre. Some towns were completely isolated from the country & even trains were stopped. Such is the severity of this European winter, the worst know for many years . The war goes on all the same. The

ground is frozen iron hard, & the walls of the trenches that a week ago were in a plastic state oozing water are now as solid as rock, and as dry as they are hard, while no mans land is a white mantle of snow frozen hard. 

The shells are now more deadly, instead of burying themselves in the mud, & much of their energy expended in throwing up geysers of mud, they explode on the hard surface spreading death & destruction in all directions within their range. 

It is considered marvellous that the Australians stand the cold so well. All day long the temperature is never above freezing point, but there are numerous cases of trench feet for it is not possible to keep them warm, though all wear two pairs of socks, but with the continual contact with the cold ground the boots get icy cold. 

On the 25 another white star liner the Laurentic used as an auxiliary cruiser was sunk by mine or torpedo off the

coast of Ireland. 125 of the crew were saved. The Russians have met with some successes near Riga & on the Rumanian front, It is now the turn of the tide & I fully expect that there will be a continued series of successes for our allies on the Eastern front until the Hun is brought to his knees.
Entry.151:
There was a fall of snow last night, & it continued to fall lightly until dinner time. The doctor put another forment this time on my left foot, as it is now worse than the right one. He also got another doctor (an English one) to have a look at it. 

Sgt McKaphie of the Signallers came into this ward this evening suffering from boils. Joe Carrol of the signallers is also in this hospitle but in another ward. 

Brigade Major is now in charge of out Battalion in place of the colonel who is in England indisposed. A raid a few days ago by our Battalion was not an unqualified success for we lost 

20 men two sargents & Lieut Power who used to be a sargent in B. Company . They however inflicted considerable punishment upon the enemy. 

There is not much war news in the papers today . An old french lady comes in every morning selling papers. She charged 2½ for the "Morning Post" a 1d London paper. When I asked for a reduction because I was a regular customer she replied "No compree"
Entry.152:
A bright clear day, but very cold. The snowing has ceased. About 1 o`clock there were several enemy aeroplanes about. Our guns fired innumerable shots art them but they failed to hit them. They were so high. Our shots had the effect of keeping them high & so preventing them observing. They were dispersed by our own aeroplanes coming on the scene. 

Today I went for a walk for the first time since I entered the Hosphile. I went round to the canteen. It is opposite a very big church with a high spire. As the door was open I went in and had a

good look around. It is beautifully fitted up inside and is capable of holding I should judge close on a thousand people. It is fitted with chairs instead of seats ,& they were all placed facing the wrong way round. It was fitted with many fine statutes & the usual pharnaphela common to all catholic churches. There were also 4 confessional boxes 2 on each side, and also a life size model of our Saviour in the manger, with his mother, Joseph, & the sheppards, and in the stalls were a donkey & a cow. It would attract more than passing interest. 

Before I went back to the hospitle I had a good feed of eggs and chips & a cup of coffee costing 1½ francs. 

I met Sargeant now Lieut. McNicol, I congratulated him on his promotion. He wishes to be remembered to friends when I am writing home. I met Joe Carrol who is in another ward suffering from bronchitis & rhumertism. I forgot to say that Lieut McNicol is attending a school in Steenwerck.
Entry.153:
It is icey cold today. But the sky is clear & the sun is shining brightly, but it is yet so low in the heavens that it has not much effect on the temperature. 

The papers announce today that Germany intends to sink hospital ships alleging that they are used to convey troops & munitions. She also boasts that she has sunk over 4 million tons of allied shipping over 3 million of it being British. 

The woman & a man have been arrested in England on a charge of conspiracy to murder the Premier & Mr Henderson. Mr Long in a speech at a war loan meeting said England intended to hold the captured German colonies. The "Daily News" thinks the announcement was ill timed. Its omission in the note to President Wilson was the in America for some previous tributes to the disinterestedness of Great Britain. 

I had dinner in the large tent or marque today for the first time, because I was able to walk about with the boots on. Then I went over to a neighbouring Estaiment, had a good warm at the stove and a few beers. I then went to the Canteen and bought

a quarter lb tin of Three Nuns Tobacco for 2 francs 7½. Also a small bottle of ink for 3d. It was frozen hard and I had to melt it on the stove before I could put it in my pen
Entry.154:
It was cold as usual last night, but today the sky is clear and sun is shining brightly. The papers are all filled with horror at the announcement of Germany`s war on the world ships contained in a note to America. Neutral vessels are to be sunk at sight, and neutral countries threatened with ruin & starvation. All the allied waters in Europe to be closed to all sea traffic. Mines will be used as well as submarines, an insulting concession is made to America. Viz. a passenger steamer will be permitted to ply weekly between Falmouth & the United States, arriving on Sundays and leaving again on Wednesday. It must take a specific course and be painted a specific design. Holland is given the privilege of one paddle steamer a week to England. American opinion is ablaze irrespective of

party or attitude towards the war. The New York "World" declared that the note is "in effect, a declaration of war against the United States. " New York Harbour was sealed throughout Wednesday night by American war ships. Vessels were allowed to leave yesterday at their own risk. All the newpapers are unanimous including those that were pro-German , in denouncing the german intentions, and demand at once a definate announcement of U. S. attidude. 

I had another walk around today, and visited the Y. M. C. A. I brought back a loaf of French bread and a tin of sardines, which we had for tea, in addition to our ration of ham and bread and beetroot. This is the first time we had ham for tea. 

We were served out with an additional blanket tonight. A gift from Australia, by the Red Cross. The blanket bore a ticket, cotton & wool made in France. This is only an instance how money and energy is wasted in the army, and by well intentioned folk. Had the money been sent to

France to purchase the blankets, the freight to and from Australia would have been saved .
Entry.155:
A beautiful day. I had a warm bed last night. The extra blanket made all the difference. There was another heavy frost last night. The old lady with newspapers has not turned up this morning, although it is long past her usual time. We fear that she is not going to come. After dinner I had a walk around the town discovered a watch maker and got a new glass and a hand on my watch costing 6d. 

I tried to get a newpaper, but failed. I was told there were no trains this morning. We had no papers last Sunday. 

 I bought a small book of French & English words price 4d. 

Tonight Sgt. McKay and another patient from the 11th machne gunners and I went out to tea. We had chips, 2 eggs and beefsteak, bread & tea . A good feed for 2 francs 1d

When we came back Charlie Cunningham was in the Hospital suffering from a frost bitten toe. He informed us that the pioneers are in the front line trenches on another sector on the right of Hooplines. The companies are away at raiding school, & the trenches are held by Head Quarters Details. In a raid by our Battalion before leaving they lost a number of men that I knew very well. Fred Neal formerly of the pioneers is dead or missing and Pte. Hooper of D. Company died at the dressing station.
Entry.156:
A dull cloudy morning with a little misty rain. C. Cunningham is to go on to another hospital at Balieul as he is likely to loose his big toe. 

The papers this morning say that America has suspended diplomatic relations with Germany . War is likely. I expected to go out this morning but the doctor said it was better to stay another day. . I had a walk around after dinner today. 

We went out again to night and had a tea of beef steak , eggs & chips which we thoroughly enjoyed.
Entry.157:
A cool frosty morning but the sky is clear and the sun is shining brightly but it is so low in the sky that its rays has little effect on the temperature. 

The Sunday papers from London arrived this morning. They announce that the United States have severed diplomatic relations with Germany and that war is imminent. The next few weeks will be momentous in the history of the waring nations. Washington has decided to hand passports to Count Bernstorff and to recall Mr. Gerard. Whether there will be an actual declaration of war depends upon Germany`s conduct. Coming events will be fraught with the most important consequences in the progress of the world war. The decision of other neutral nations , especially Spain and the S. American Republics will be watched with the greatest interest. It is

stated that U. S. A. is prepared for any eventuality. 

I was greatly surprised that I had not to go out this morning to the reinforcement camp, but the doctor, the major, said to leave in another day. I am not sorry. 

I had tea in the marquie this evening of boiled rice, bread & butter & hot tea. The tent is frightfully cold and their is no tempetation to linger over one`s meals.
Entry.158:
Very cold this morning, the sky is clear and the sun is shining brightly. There is a cold E. N. E. Wind. Yesterdays papers confirm the news of America`s "break" with Germany. Vast preparations are being made in the event of war. America intends to carry on the war on a vast scale if forced to join in. 

At 2 o`clock I was paraded with others and marched to a rest camp about half a mile away. Here I will remain for a few days before rejoining my unit. The rest camp consists of wooden huts with two decker beds I received a single bed on 

 top. There was a very heavy frost last night and the hut was very cold despite the stove. Each hut holds 56 men.
Entry.159:
Very cold this morning. I was up about 7. a. m. paraded to the doctor as my heel was very sore. At 10 o`clock we were paraded to the baths. I thoroughly enjoyed the showers, the first for over a month. 

There is not much news in the papers this morning. I went out at dinner time and had 2 drinks of beer at an estaminet near railway station.
Entry.160:
It was exceedingly cold last night and this morning. There is 1 ft. thick of ice on a pond near the camp. There is a whole made in it with a pick to get water for washing. 

I paraded sick this morning & got some whale oil for my feet and a dose of medicine for my cold. There was an inspection this afternoon, and we had to clean up the billets for it. The food is very poor here, caused chiefly by poor cooks being on the job

There was some very heavy straffing last night and again this afternoon by our artillery. We can distinctly hear the boom of heavy guns in the distance. I have not been able to get a paper today anywhere. Tonight I paid a visit to the hospital to see my mate Sargent McKay and others. They will not be out for a few days yet. They are getting on splendid. I brought them a few chocolates.
Entry.161:
Very cold this morning and today. We had an early breakfast and a poor one. We then packed up out kits and at 9. 30 about 20 of us marched into Armentieres, arriving here about 12. 30. It was a long weary march for those coming out of the hospital, especially those with sore feet. I had my full pack to carry. We had dinner at the Quartermasters store about 1. 30. and we, ,this is the other man from the 37. Battalion. Private Kidman thoroughly. Those who marched into from the hospital comprised men from several other Battalions. 

Houplines is 2 K7. from half past Eleven Square and Frelinghen 5K. 3. 

Sunday Feb. 11. 1917

Last night Lieut Cerity asked me to stay the night as he had some work for me to do. I did so, & was glad of the chance to stay . My company came out of the trenches last night. I went up to see them this morning, and got one letter from Kitty Gilmore at H. 2. Post office today I got a letter from Willie dated Dec7. & written from Military Camp Maribyrnong. Also one from Cis dated Dec. 8. and two from Lizzie dated
Entry.162: and 7. and numbered 35 & 36. I was cleaning out the Q. M. store today.
Entry.163:
There was a light fall of snow this morning when I got up about 8. 30. Last night there was a heavy and continuous artillery activity by our artillery commencing about eleven o`clock and continuing for several hours. There was a raid on, and I heard this morning that it was successful, prisoners and a german officer being captured. 

I done a little fatigue work this

morning. Kito of D. company who came out of the hospital with me left after dinner to rejoin his unit. 

The "Weekly Dispatch" of yesterday says that German U. Boats have sunk 81 ships since the first of this month. 

Tonight I received another parcel from my dear wife containing 2 plugs of dark Havelock tobacco and 2 plugs of light Havelock tobacco. I very much appreciated them as they are a delightful change form the issue tobacco, which is generally of inferior quality.
Entry.164:
A dull cloudy day looks like rain. This morning I cleaned up the billets here and the store. 

I have received up to the last payment Jan 24/17. £14-14-1 less forfeiture 15/- for being absent 3 days without leave. In the afternoon I was helping H. Quarters cook. 

Wednesday February 14. 1917

A nice clear day but rather cold. In fact it is freezing again. Last night I wrote to Kithy Martin and to Cis. This morning I was agreably surprised to get 5 letters from my dear wife, dated Dec. 10 numbered 37.
Entry.165:
No 37. 

Dec. 17. No 38. Dec. 21. No 39 and Dec 21 No 40. 

I was very sorry to learn that Lizzie`s mother passed away at Merino on Dec. 17. 

It was not a surprise to me as she had been in very indifferent health for a long time, and Lizzie was constantly telling me that she was continually getting worse, though rallying occasionally, but only again to get worse. I wrote to Lizzie today. a letter of sympathy 3 pages. Also a short description of the place. 

Our Battalion is out at present, being in various training schools for some time,. A section of our Battalion mostly H. 2. details and some men from the 38 Battalion have been in the trenches as one unit and known as X Battalion or company. Some of them are going back into the trenches tonight, and some tomorrow. The Pioneers are in hopes that we will not have to go in this time, unless it is as Pioneers.
